class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> Minezaki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>); MacLeod et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf6\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Jackson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf7\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> Patnaik et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf8\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf8\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup> Obtained from macromodelling, rather than from observed IR or radio data. Errors in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}$|</span> added to observed errors in quadrature (see Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2.2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2.3</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991289\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991290 id=\"118991290\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-3>4.2.3 Microlensing simulations</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We use a Bayesian analysis to constrain the size of the quasar accretion disc <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> at \u03bb<sub>0</sub> = 1026\u00c5, and the power-law index <em>p</em>. The radial profile of the accretion disc is assumed to be of the form <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\nr = r_s \\left(\\frac{\\lambda }{\\lambda _0}\\right)^p.\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>We use Gaussian profiles to describe the shape of the disc at each wavelength; the measured sizes <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> are Gaussian dispersions. Mortonson, Schechter &amp; Wambsganss (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) have demonstrated that size estimates from microlensing simulations are independent of the detailed surface brightness profile shapes, but rather depend only on the characteristic width of that profile.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, we vary parameters on a regular grid, such that <em>ln</em>(<em>r<sub>s</sub></em>) = 0.3 \u00d7 <em>j</em> for <em>j</em> = 0\u202611, and <em>p</em> = 0.25 \u00d7 <em>i</em> for <em>i</em> = 0\u202615. This is a slightly larger range in <em>p</em> than in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each combination of <em>ln</em>(<em>r<sub>s</sub></em>), <em>p</em>, and <em>s</em>, the magnification maps for image 1 and image 2 are convolved with a series of Gaussian source profiles with dispersion <em>r</em> calculated at the rest-frame wavelengths of the observations using equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>). Each map is then sampled on a regular grid of 10<sup>4</sup> points. This allows us to construct 10<sup>8</sup> simulated magnification ratios per <em>ln</em>(<em>r<sub>s</sub></em>)-<em>p</em>-<em>s</em> parameter combination for comparison with the observational data. We note that we sample only from the central 2000\u00a0\u00d7 2000\u00a0pixel area of each magnification map; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10\\, 000 \\times 10\\, 000$|</span> pixel maps allow us to convolve with large source profiles while avoiding convolution edge effects. The effective upper limit on our simulated source sizes is 8 Einstein radii.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Errors in the unmicrolensed baseline affect observed flux ratios at each wavelength equivalently: they simply act as a systematic offset. To account for this, we include the unmicrolensed baseline <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}$|</span> as a nuisance parameter in our Bayesian analysis. At each of the 10<sup>8</sup> simulated observations, we re-sample <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}$|</span> from a Gaussian with mean and dispersion equal to the observed unmicrolensed baseline and its error (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), and re-normalize the observed data. This effectively marginalizes over errors in the unmicrolensed baseline.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that this differs from the usual technique (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>), where the error in the unmicrolensed baseline is simply added into the observed errors in quadrature. This is equivalent to assuming that errors in the baseline affect each wavelength independently, rather than systematically.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We construct likelihoods <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}_k$|</span> for each simulated observation <em>k</em> using a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> comparison: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\mathcal {L}_k(\\Delta m_{\\rm micro}|ln(r_s), p, s) = \\rm {exp}\\left(\\frac{-\\chi _k^2}{2}\\right).\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>The final likelihood for a given combination of parameters <em>ln</em>(<em>r<sub>s</sub></em>), <em>p, s</em> is simply the sum over all of the likelihoods of the individual simulated observations <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L} = \\sum _k \\mathcal {L}_k$|\u2060</span>.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Differential probability distributions are generated from the likelihoods using Bayes\u2019 theorem: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation*}\r\n\\frac{\\rm {d}^3P}{\\rm {d}ln(r_s)\\rm {d}p\\rm {d}s} \\propto \\mathcal {L}(\\Delta m_{\\rm micro}|ln(r_s), p, s)\\frac{\\rm {d}P_{\\rm prior}}{\\rm {d}ln(r_s)}\\frac{\\rm {d}P_{\\rm prior}}{\\rm {d}p}\\frac{\\rm {d}P_{\\rm prior}}{\\rm {d}s}.\r\n\\end{equation*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>We use flat priors for all three parameters (equivalent to a logarithmic prior on the source size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>). Since we are interested in the quasar accretion discs, we integrate over <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {d}s$|</span> as a nuisance parameter. Results are presented as mean values with 68 per cent confidence intervals, or 68 per cent upper/lower limits where appropriate.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991298 id=\"118991298\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Probability distributions for the accretion disc parameters in each of our four systems are provided in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, marginalized over the smooth matter fraction and errors in the unmicrolensed baseline. In each figure we have marked the power-law index of an SS disc with a dashed red line (<em>p</em> = 4/3), and the Bayesian ensemble estimate from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> with a hashed region (<em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2).</p>                        <a id=\"118991300\" scrollto-destination=\"118991300\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=hBqDaze2n9yzy-DoyeXhJydoRSIEcZn3OjPhnG6jJdqRLCdyrUlNO20oamMAf3wYAj0nWWpL-icS-mGSRHD9MM7PtTgg~iQCSrDvl5c93xbuy2aFV1TgqkoGZpvFFOs3Pl90AnZJkRzefCAXm3IAKaQHtNAMAljjQrqbUYN8jAaVqY2qCse0Ljqrrwic2SNydQwGfsTe5MVrCdkUVbUSsEhCYTCnGnEFzyyK2YdTt9jR00zSjAH4LtG4a1dojKL9BCMCfnrdibbnxnBCQk3HWUhEkD2u-ygmVNY9bdkSGgjWEvIPBJekh1WcCCDtxiamtXkc2QnIqYDoIavIYNZIdQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Accretion disc constraints for four lensed quasars using our HST data only. Contours are drawn at intervals of 0.5\u03c3 (thick lines at 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3) for two degrees of freedom from the maximum. The solid contours therefore formally contain 68.3 and 95.4 per cent of the probability. The dashed red line marks the power-law index for the SS disc (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev 1973). The hatched region is the joint 1\u03c3 constraint from JV14. Panel (b): RXJ 0911+0551. Panel (c): B 1422+231. Contours are drawn at intervals of 0.5\u03c3 (thick lines at 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3) for two degrees of freedom from the maximum. The solid contours therefore formally contain 68.3 and 95.4 per cent of the probability. Panel (d): WFI J2026-4536.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=hBqDaze2n9yzy-DoyeXhJydoRSIEcZn3OjPhnG6jJdqRLCdyrUlNO20oamMAf3wYAj0nWWpL-icS-mGSRHD9MM7PtTgg~iQCSrDvl5c93xbuy2aFV1TgqkoGZpvFFOs3Pl90AnZJkRzefCAXm3IAKaQHtNAMAljjQrqbUYN8jAaVqY2qCse0Ljqrrwic2SNydQwGfsTe5MVrCdkUVbUSsEhCYTCnGnEFzyyK2YdTt9jR00zSjAH4LtG4a1dojKL9BCMCfnrdibbnxnBCQk3HWUhEkD2u-ygmVNY9bdkSGgjWEvIPBJekh1WcCCDtxiamtXkc2QnIqYDoIavIYNZIdQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Accretion disc constraints for four lensed quasars using our HST data only. Contours are drawn at intervals of 0.5\u03c3 (thick lines at 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3) for two degrees of freedom from the maximum. The solid contours therefore formally contain 68.3 and 95.4 per cent of the probability. The dashed red line marks the power-law index for the SS disc (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev 1973). Panel (b): RXJ 0911+0551. Panel (c): B 1422+231. Panel (d): WFI J2026-4536.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991300/sty1793fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991300\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=Qq-al5rxWbpro-FTNLRNv7LsJXrBz-eHFyWClAfhgYNX0ZYfP6SGb-BIqonwI0ETxM5bs5nmXJJRJ72w37~8QaLu56e9GgOCm7HxbnEAR5LxDMqnRTlIv63fHE0EPQeYDPlKAhG~pKqqlzP1-trqsifh~ULpyurdE7t1L4~J1zJOlJiXq6pi6wvazR3b9Ykk7BEQq3vw9tZ5quY5il0QNUh22K7Sf6wfjvyoCbPSyjQ0Cidy96upkiwPgmHVFBTaqh6JhwQI6i~CC200f4cpR-4k5MWekKMphxYTp-sxGMJsd3spoj6wH2XwxkiOR-uTOqWnHTZTy5e4r3kZUXQG5Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991300&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Accretion disc constraints for four lensed quasars using our <em>HST</em> data only. Contours are drawn at intervals of 0.5\u03c3 (thick lines at 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3) for two degrees of freedom from the maximum. The solid contours therefore formally contain 68.3 and 95.4 per cent of the probability. The dashed red line marks the power-law index for the SS disc (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1973</a>). The hatched region is the joint 1\u03c3 constraint from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>. The red cross marks the peak probability in the two-dimensional surface, and the dotted light blue line is the limit of our simulations (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>). Panel (a): MG 0414+0534. Panel (b): RXJ 0911+0551. Panel (c): B 1422+231. Panel (d): WFI J2026-4536.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The dotted light blue line in each figure marks the point at which the combination of parameters <em>ln</em>(<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>) and <em>p</em> gives a source size in the reddest filter that is larger than we can fit in our 100 Einstein radius maps (this limit is a Gaussian dispersion of 8 Einstein radii). Beyond this point, we simply assume that the simulated flux ratio equals the unmicrolensed macroflux ratio. In most cases this is a reasonable assumption, however large-scale structures in sheared magnification maps (conglomerations of caustics stacked on top of each other) can still cause slight deviation from the macroflux ratio, even at these sizes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although there may be some probability that the true accretion disc parameters lie beyond this dotted light blue line (specifically in MG 0414+0534and WFI J2026-4536), we do not expect it to be significant. In any case, if we expanded the maximum size limitations in our simulations the measured <em>p</em> constraints could only skew to higher values, pushing them further away from the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> result.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The formal 68 per cent constraints obtained from these probability distributions are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. We quote results after marginalizing over the smooth matter fraction <em>s</em>, as well as the constraints obtained if we assume <em>s</em> = 0.8. The most notable feature of these measurements and the probability distributions in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> is their diversity, particularly when compared with <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> or Blackburne et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The reasons for these differences will be discussed in the following section.</p>                        <a id=\"118991304\" scrollto-destination=\"118991304\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 8.</span><div per cent smooth matter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>System<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Marginalized<span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>System<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r<sub>s</sub></em> (light-day)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG 0414+0534\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.9\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.1^{+0.6}_{-0.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.5\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.8^{+0.6}_{-0.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ 0911+0551\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5.1^{+8.2}_{-3.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.6^{+0.7}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$6.8^{+5.6}_{-4.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.4^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.2\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.4^{+0.4}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.9\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.3^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991304\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 8.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured accretion disc constraints (68 per cent).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">Marginalized<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"2\">80 per cent smooth matter<span .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>p</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG no-formula-id\">|$1.6^{+0.7}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$6.8^{+5.6}_{-4.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.4^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.2\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.4^{+0.4}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.9\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.3^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991304\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show the explicit dependence of our accretion disc constraints on the assumed smooth matter fraction <em>s</em> in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (RXJ 0911+0551 is excluded from this figure; the data for this system do not provide constraints at any smooth matter fraction). With a few exceptions, we obtain only upper limits on the size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> of the accretion disc at \u03bb<sub>0</sub> = 1026\u00c5 (in B 1422+231we obtain a measurement, but its error bars are large). For the power-law index <em>p</em>, we find the marginalized constraints are completely consistent with each of the individual smooth matter cases, tending to deviate only at <em>s</em> = 0.99. There is a slight trend towards decreasing <em>p</em> (steepening temperature profile) with increasing <em>s</em>, most pronounced in MG 0414+0534.</p>                        <a id=\"118991306\" scrollto-destination=\"118991306\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=ltXIgsEerTsDoAb~xw6m5qmBVd-i6GMDICeyL1d3K5v9Wk1y-LRyVif9nRQnRH~TsyDv0TznedP-XwUOkRjwNEUMgm-syzBpGwLcsGwhzCmdt6~XlxlxqFcqrZ2njEyqhTeVyME9G8PSpysS28dHROmJznjV3CvgBbeRpmAKDi8fdkxq7dAz5ExjMD5LzBrbCmd3LayJgNZB87pd~DTNYpVc1IlbrPB~zP28zAL0NvN2KXnXREyQ4fBwIAISfDghevAJfnvXua19~051v6JhDtX-8fWH2fDffUHWXW1f5glQiF-8JCoZG3u--RgOMLqib6Njf-t5eCIzZqenvcR~Yg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Variation of accretion disc constraints as a function of smooth matter fraction s. Error bars denote 68 per cent confidence. Arrows are 68 per cent upper limits (s = 0.6 in B 1422+231is a lower limit). The top panels show size constraints rs. The bottom panels show constraints on the temperature profile power-law index p. Blue lines indicate the constraints obtained when marginalizing over s. In the top left (MG 0414+0534) and top right (WFI J2026-4536) panels, these are 68 per cent upper limits. In all other panels, the solid blue lines show the marginalized constraint, and the dotted blue lines the 68 per cent confidence limits. The Shakura-Sunyaev power-law index p = 4/3 is plotted as a dashed red line in the bottom panels.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991306/sty1793fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991306\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=BNMnnIBPTpFeiE71gTPPfKByg8TXuR6B-are5xCVAFRFJ7T41rnf06uVXvFoLV26JY3xIDnPafLBJSV8Y3htiJdRk-v-qhUgVjXu0SEWxsjEs3eziGwA60qUXQG6ilEE3907O5mm1AkPysmK-a1QrMhrLt4EQguBAzLM5WsAuP6RrNswQ6Dat51WFusEGhF5q-xd1iwZW1Bci7blKdKtsxmQXuonubLQQYzvH6mboc4JUjF6Z64Nkc1fkVirsrqC0kjtmkgi202aijTzPsAlpj65EtiPLrpocl5S0CWBk1PpuG8w4i-dIWUG2hLeTfaxPAfRAhggqoHeJEfHy6ChYg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991306&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Variation of accretion disc constraints as a function of smooth matter fraction <em>s</em>. Error bars denote 68 per cent confidence. Arrows are 68 per cent upper limits (<em>s</em> = 0.6 in B 1422+231is a lower limit). The top panels show size constraints <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>. The bottom panels show constraints on the temperature profile power-law index <em>p</em>. Blue lines indicate the constraints obtained when marginalizing over <em>s</em>. In the top left (MG 0414+0534) and top right (WFI J2026-4536) panels, these are 68 per cent upper limits. In all other panels, the solid blue lines show the marginalized constraint, and the dotted blue lines the 68 per cent confidence limits. The Shakura-Sunyaev power-law index <em>p</em> = 4/3 is plotted as a dashed red line in the bottom panels.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=ltXIgsEerTsDoAb~xw6m5qmBVd-i6GMDICeyL1d3K5v9Wk1y-LRyVif9nRQnRH~TsyDv0TznedP-XwUOkRjwNEUMgm-syzBpGwLcsGwhzCmdt6~XlxlxqFcqrZ2njEyqhTeVyME9G8PSpysS28dHROmJznjV3CvgBbeRpmAKDi8fdkxq7dAz5ExjMD5LzBrbCmd3LayJgNZB87pd~DTNYpVc1IlbrPB~zP28zAL0NvN2KXnXREyQ4fBwIAISfDghevAJfnvXua19~051v6JhDtX-8fWH2fDffUHWXW1f5glQiF-8JCoZG3u--RgOMLqib6Njf-t5eCIzZqenvcR~Yg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Variation of accretion disc constraints as a function of smooth matter fraction s. Error bars denote 68 per cent confidence. Arrows are 68 per cent upper limits (s = 0.6 in B 1422+231is a lower limit). The top panels show size constraints rs. The bottom panels show constraints on the temperature profile power-law index p. Blue lines indicate the constraints obtained when marginalizing over s. In the top left (MG 0414+0534) and top right (WFI J2026-4536) panels, these are 68 per cent upper limits. In all other panels, the solid blue lines show the marginalized constraint, and the dotted blue lines the 68 per cent confidence limits. The Shakura-Sunyaev power-law index p = 4/3 is plotted as a dashed red line in the bottom panels.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991306/sty1793fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991306\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=BNMnnIBPTpFeiE71gTPPfKByg8TXuR6B-are5xCVAFRFJ7T41rnf06uVXvFoLV26JY3xIDnPafLBJSV8Y3htiJdRk-v-qhUgVjXu0SEWxsjEs3eziGwA60qUXQG6ilEE3907O5mm1AkPysmK-a1QrMhrLt4EQguBAzLM5WsAuP6RrNswQ6Dat51WFusEGhF5q-xd1iwZW1Bci7blKdKtsxmQXuonubLQQYzvH6mboc4JUjF6Z64Nkc1fkVirsrqC0kjtmkgi202aijTzPsAlpj65EtiPLrpocl5S0CWBk1PpuG8w4i-dIWUG2hLeTfaxPAfRAhggqoHeJEfHy6ChYg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991306&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Variation of accretion disc constraints as a function of smooth matter fraction <em>s</em>. Error bars denote 68 per cent confidence. Arrows are 68 per cent upper limits (<em>s</em> = 0.6 in B 1422+231is a lower limit). The top panels show size constraints <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>. The bottom panels show constraints on the temperature profile power-law index <em>p</em>. Blue lines indicate the constraints obtained when marginalizing over <em>s</em>. In the top left (MG 0414+0534) and top right (WFI J2026-4536) panels, these are 68 per cent upper limits. In all other panels, the solid blue lines show the marginalized constraint, and the dotted blue lines the 68 per cent confidence limits. The Shakura-Sunyaev power-law index <em>p</em> = 4/3 is plotted as a dashed red line in the bottom panels.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the remainder of this paper, we restrict ourselves to discussing results for the <em>s</em> = 0.8 case. We choose this value following Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>), who measured <em>s</em> = 0.79 \u00b1 0.14 from a sample of 19 lensed quasars. We note, however, that this specific constraint is not uniformly applied in the literature: for example, Rojas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and Motta et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) use <em>s</em> = 0.9, and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> used <em>s</em> = 0.95.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991308 id=\"118991308\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991309 id=\"118991309\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Accretion disc size <em>r</em><sub><em>s</em></sub></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The accretion disc sizes quoted in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> are Gaussian dispersions, assuming 1M<sub>\u2299</sub> microlenses. To facilitate comparisons with thin-disc theory, we convert to half-light radii <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{1/2} = 1.18\\, r_s$|\u2060</span>. The average stellar microlens in a lensing galaxy is likely to be less massive than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1\\, \\text{M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>; the standard value used is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm micro}=0.3\\, \\text{M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, which enters into our source sizes as a factor of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(M_{\\rm micro}/M_\\odot)^{1/2}$|\u2060</span>. Our resulting half-light radius measurements assuming <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.3\\, \\text{M}_\\odot$|</span> microlenses are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118991311\" scrollto-destination=\"118991311\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 9.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured accretion disc half-light radii (68 per cent).</p></div> </div><div aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH}$|</span> (10<sup>9</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>/<em>r</em><sub>nthin</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> (light-day)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH}$|</span> (10<sup>9</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>: Results assuming smooth matter fraction <em>s</em> = 0.8.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> From Mosquera &amp; Kochanek (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Fiducial value; no measured black hole mass available.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991311\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 9.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measured accretion disc half-light radii (68 per cent).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>System<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> (light-day)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH}$|</span> (10<sup>9</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>/<em>r</em><sub>nthin</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG 0414+0534\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.6\u00a0</td><td>1.82\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ 0911+0551\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.80\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$4.4^{+3.6}_{-2.8}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>4.79\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.3^{+1.9}_{-1.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.9\u00a0</td><td>1.00<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.8\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>System<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> (light-day)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH}$|</span> (10<sup>9</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>)<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub>/<em>r</em><sub>nthin</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG 0414+0534\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.6\u00a0</td><td>1.82\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ 0911+0551\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.80\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$4.4^{+3.6}_{-2.8}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>4.79\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.3^{+1.9}_{-1.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>&lt;1.9\u00a0</td><td>1.00<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;2.8\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>: Results assuming smooth matter fraction <em>s</em> = 0.8.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> From Mosquera &amp; Kochanek (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Fiducial value; no measured black hole mass available.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991311\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The half-light radius of a standard thin disc (Shakura &amp; Sunyaev <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1973</a>) is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nr_{\\rm {thin}} &amp;=&amp; 2.44\\left(\\frac{45G^2M^2_{\\rm BH}m_pf_{\\rm Edd}\\lambda ^4}{4\\pi ^5h_pc^3\\sigma _T\\eta }\\right)^{1/3}\\sqrt{\\rm {cos}\\ i} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; 6.49 \\rm {ld} \\left(\\frac{M_{\\rm BH}}{10^9\\text{M}_\\odot }\\right)^{2/3} \\left(\\frac{f_{\\rm Edd}}{\\eta }\\right)^{1/3} \\left(\\frac{\\lambda }{\\mu \\rm {m}}\\right)^{4/3},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH}$|</span> is the black hole mass, <em>m</em><sub>p</sub> is the proton mass, <em>h</em><sub>p</sub> is Planck\u2019s constant, \u03c3<sub>T</sub> is the Thomson scattering cross-section, and <em>i</em> is the inclination angle (assumed to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\rm {cos}\\ i\\rangle = 1/2$|\u2060</span>). <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm Edd}$|</span> is the Eddington ratio, the ratio of the quasar\u2019s bolometric luminosity to the Eddington luminosity, and \u03b7 is the accretion efficiency. Finally, \u03bb is the rest wavelength of interest.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Black hole mass measurements are available for three of our systems: MG 0414+0534, RXJ 0911+0551, and B 1422+231(Mosquera &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). For WFI J2026-4536, we assume a fiducial <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm BH} = 10^9 \\text{M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>. In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we provide black hole masses and ratios of measured half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>1/2</sub> to the thin disc prediction <em>r</em><sub>nthin</sub>, calculated using equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For MG 0414+0534and WFI J2026-4536, our two systems showing the largest chromatic variation, we obtain only upper limits. Nevertheless, in line with previous microlensing analyses, we find that our measured sizes are consistent with being larger than expected from thin disc theory (only marginally, in the case of MG 0414+0534). In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, they quoted an ensemble measurement of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_s = 4.5^{+1.5}_{-1.2}$|</span> light-days for eight quasars (assuming <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1\\, \\text{M}_\\odot$|</span> microlenses). Converting that to half-light radius as described above, their constraint is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{1/2} = 2.9^{+1.0}_{-0.8}$|</span> light-days. This is marginally larger than our measurement for MG 0414+0534, and completely consistent with our B 1422+231and WFI J2026-4536results.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991315 id=\"118991315\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Power-law index <em>p</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, the authors report a Bayesian estimate of the power-law index <em>p</em> of 0.8 \u00b1 0.2, measured jointly from eight lensed quasars. The accretion disc temperature profile goes as <em>T</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>r</em><sup>\u22121/<em>p</em></sup>, so this corresponds to a steeper temperature profile than expected for an SS disc.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This steep temperature profile measurement is difficult to understand in the context of microlensing light-curve constraints on accretion disc sizes (e.g. Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), or recent reverberation mapping experiments (e.g. Jiang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Starkey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), which consistently measure accretion discs to be factors of\u00a0\u223c4 larger than expected from thin disc theory. Naively, you would expect that larger accretion discs at a given wavelength imply shallower temperature profiles.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have measured <em>p</em> in four additional systems, and we prefer <em>larger</em> values of <em>p</em> than 4/3 in two of our systems: WFI J2026-4536and MG 0414+0534 (marginally). Both of these results are consistent with the <em>p</em> = 2.0 slim disc prescription of Abramowicz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>). In the third system, B 1422+231, we find <em>p</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a04/3 is preferred, consistent with standard SS thin discs. Our RXJ 0911+0551 data are insufficient to place any constraints on its accretion disc structure.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Why do we find such a variety of constraints on <em>p</em>, where the measurements in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> were largely consistent with each other, converging on <em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2? In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, we plot all of the observations reported in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (black triangles, from their Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) and this paper (red circles). The figure shows absolute magnitude differences between lensed images as a function of rest wavelength in each quasar. The variation in absolute magnitude difference between shortest and longest wavelength represents the degree of microlensing-induced chromatic variation in each system.</p>                        <a id=\"118991320\" scrollto-destination=\"118991320\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=2R-7dPHfPCbhx1eD8YBrY6heTMe8ybQDMACLzB~yy7CL7A3s63VdLAbzKYKxVfN1I-4fedbRHit57qzQ-Zp3-U8kKtIoxa5nE~LgN5HDnE7cdlCpcIxoXNgO9pR4yqu6THcdKyO0yDRr4c9P-YhawFicfA-gz4fqfi~PKaH~Wy8CyXFFeE2GNRGyvwRwDH7wWugTyQmVvkSL5CdTD9gZoY3fmJhp~Zn5OFlIg4vyVO-E1zns~1XrcPX5HJXbFSdcEk9G5FKxV9PMpmWeJzbv1UdQta58wrTSzewnk9BkcORoxb2HYJXlT6rdnwp6BZ5R1RgcNJ08vNgV1afGjyPNJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Absolute values of observed magnitude differences between lensed images, normalized to their expected macromagnifications (errors in our HST data are largely dominated by errors in the expected macromagnifications; see Tables\u00a03 and\u00a07). The red circles are four sets of observations reported in this paper, whereas the black triangles are the sample from JV14 (excluding Q 2237+0305, the data for which were not provided in that paper). B \u2212 A is adopted for labelling convenience; in MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536, A = A1 and B = A2. The label for B 1422+231 is omitted from the plot for clarity. It is clear from this figure that MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536 show a much greater degree of chromatic variation than any of the systems in the JV14 sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991320/sty1793fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991320\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=xmBsIDMW9wPlQKeH8Tb8xo-nq2hv4RbGcHlVf6F5oEF~TJ~OB7BdSnsFnkvvrBzgkifw7sBePxvysN-W4cvCoduObNpD7C-D9bRUZDy7njeNcSlbMYi3N3x5ol7EQnAvAV~dqZuDGAr~MKZrqJmw61B5-~SAVc8yuYhG-xwI0Ecvshxi1pSiyUdTEGQfjQU1LVzqJR9BT0AMe6~ZAaUecuKeXjPsmQC4lTroBWl~VGf2Dz-m2DLB8EbXtvK~lDlC1VRuOalVFORyFO-ljfU-9gNcOY63ci7TLEHvJ8yu7X2LPAxnOcyVhfg2KThAAaWvBP2PIPkwOW~0NC~UBAOp8g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991320&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Absolute values of observed magnitude differences between lensed images, normalized to their expected macromagnifications (errors in our <em>HST</em> data are largely dominated by errors in the expected macromagnifications; see Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). The red circles are four sets of observations reported in this paper, whereas the black triangles are the sample from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (excluding Q 2237+0305, the data for which were not provided in that paper). <em>B</em> \u2212 <em>A</em> is adopted for labelling convenience; in MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536, <em>A</em> = <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>B</em> = <em>A</em><sub>2</sub>. The label for B 1422+231 is omitted from the plot for clarity. It is clear from this figure that MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536 show a much greater degree of chromatic variation than any of the systems in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=2R-7dPHfPCbhx1eD8YBrY6heTMe8ybQDMACLzB~yy7CL7A3s63VdLAbzKYKxVfN1I-4fedbRHit57qzQ-Zp3-U8kKtIoxa5nE~LgN5HDnE7cdlCpcIxoXNgO9pR4yqu6THcdKyO0yDRr4c9P-YhawFicfA-gz4fqfi~PKaH~Wy8CyXFFeE2GNRGyvwRwDH7wWugTyQmVvkSL5CdTD9gZoY3fmJhp~Zn5OFlIg4vyVO-E1zns~1XrcPX5HJXbFSdcEk9G5FKxV9PMpmWeJzbv1UdQta58wrTSzewnk9BkcORoxb2HYJXlT6rdnwp6BZ5R1RgcNJ08vNgV1afGjyPNJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Absolute values of observed magnitude differences between lensed images, normalized to their expected macromagnifications (errors in our HST data are largely dominated by errors in the expected macromagnifications; see Tables\u00a03 and\u00a07). The red circles are four sets of observations reported in this paper, whereas the black triangles are the sample from JV14 (excluding Q 2237+0305, the data for which were not provided in that paper). B \u2212 A is adopted for labelling convenience; in MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536, A = A1 and B = A2. The label for B 1422+231 is omitted from the plot for clarity. It is clear from this figure that MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536 show a much greater degree of chromatic variation than any of the systems in the JV14 sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991320/sty1793fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991320\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=xmBsIDMW9wPlQKeH8Tb8xo-nq2hv4RbGcHlVf6F5oEF~TJ~OB7BdSnsFnkvvrBzgkifw7sBePxvysN-W4cvCoduObNpD7C-D9bRUZDy7njeNcSlbMYi3N3x5ol7EQnAvAV~dqZuDGAr~MKZrqJmw61B5-~SAVc8yuYhG-xwI0Ecvshxi1pSiyUdTEGQfjQU1LVzqJR9BT0AMe6~ZAaUecuKeXjPsmQC4lTroBWl~VGf2Dz-m2DLB8EbXtvK~lDlC1VRuOalVFORyFO-ljfU-9gNcOY63ci7TLEHvJ8yu7X2LPAxnOcyVhfg2KThAAaWvBP2PIPkwOW~0NC~UBAOp8g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991320&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Absolute values of observed magnitude differences between lensed images, normalized to their expected macromagnifications (errors in our <em>HST</em> data are largely dominated by errors in the expected macromagnifications; see Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). The red circles are four sets of observations reported in this paper, whereas the black triangles are the sample from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (excluding Q 2237+0305, the data for which were not provided in that paper). <em>B</em> \u2212 <em>A</em> is adopted for labelling convenience; in MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536, <em>A</em> = <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>B</em> = <em>A</em><sub>2</sub>. The label for B 1422+231 is omitted from the plot for clarity. It is clear from this figure that MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536 show a much greater degree of chromatic variation than any of the systems in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> clearly illustrates that two of our systems \u2013 MG 0414+0534 and WFI J2026-4536 \u2013 display more chromatic variation than any of the objects studied in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>. In contrast, B 1422+231 shows chromatic microlensing effects broadly similar to the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> sample, and RXJ 0911+0551 has essentially no chromatic microlensing at all. Note that there is no overlap between the systems studied here, and those in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In cases where we observe strong chromatic effects, we find <em>p</em> &gt; 4/3, whereas in cases where chromatic effects are weaker we find <em>p</em> consistent with (or even smaller than) 4/3. If we look at the individual quasars in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> sample, two of the three systems displaying the strongest chromatic effects also provide the largest estimates of the power-law index (HE 0512-3329: maximum likelihood <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p = 1.25^{+0.6}_{-0.7}$|\u2060</span>, Bayesian <em>p</em> = 1.4 \u00b1 0.6; SDSS J1004+4112: maximum likelihood <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p = 1.00^{+1.00}_{-0.5}$|\u2060</span>, Bayesian <em>p</em> = 1.3 \u00b1 0.6). This trend is illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, where we plot the observational constraints for each system in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (black) and this work (red) as a function of the size of their chromatic variation. The latter is defined as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min}$|</span> (usually, but not always, the bluest observation minus the reddest). The error bars in the individual observations are large; formally, they are all consistent with each other, and with the SS disc prediction. Nevertheless, there does appear to be a general trend, as described above: observations with lower chromatic variation tend to predict lower values of <em>p</em>.</p>                        <a id=\"118991323\" scrollto-destination=\"118991323\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=I0msY9J3XiWoVewWgbw~DetWNd5Cv97f~AuYOn5wJD-8FoIOUlXINRUNc2H-6SEyElNMcFD707C1Jm1OAiuD5wuCRfH4pR1ZfsgPov7piLJ5cGAA~DFgE8PiLZFTJCeqB4xXkYFDzTHRsfgIIWh-R2fFx4~VE1yKPH0NPuv~Iz8kyMnDCwCiGxH~5gr7WnJ-4bnn8wNd7-sQtx8iUzdiJQboZN5JJDdKoq4VLrUzzYLp1-cbhbVI5MoMuhJnfxbQ5QnYxHpnExPyk8-qY-ntvaJYanIUw-C3mkMP6kOy0TLNlSC7yk41FiTmf87NNht8TvvNA6kMX8WyEjHDRLkkDw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Power-law constraints p (68 per cent confidence) as a function of the size of chromatic variation in the observation. As the degree of chromatic variation increases, so does the measured constraint on the power-law index. Seven quasars are presented from Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (2014) (filled black circles, Bayesian constraints), along with their joint constraint at the average chromatic variation of their sample (light blue filled circle). Three quasars from this work are shown (red stars, s = 0.80), with a vertical red line marking the degree of chromatic variation in the fourth (RXJ 0911+0551, where we obtain no constraint). The red dashed line marks the power-law index p = 4/3, appropriate for the standard SS disc.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991323/sty1793fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991323\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=yVuy4Ep798hkKqoUVQlnbZ5x3RWftjfw9JckpzjD9xzpnQbZCkl5uc4dr1JTuorakAJteqRLPOTBdH--u09Z3fKLKiLCfWVwZUHU8wIWnH3g2VbEO2LjPV3-fHN1uRsYEqni~7oftJ0b0EVNbaykkkoa7cp4eHN8J3UrmLuMMSUqb~BeTlWPht6yJnPME5hfEIUfEMf0j8HgyetikWg6WM05YZGfAlQ6qmWK8X2pqFtO5MwA7FoevuYkagkGMvE2jhZWYPR-z3Vu-VLzN2B3xXvLh-4B-HuOcIFIZoRdfxBMsRiBEIxbq~BryPZmU79mTZv6IOBmMsbFd4UxfLwfxQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991323&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Power-law constraints <em>p</em> (68 per cent confidence) as a function of the size of chromatic variation in the observation. As the degree of chromatic variation increases, so does the measured constraint on the power-law index. Seven quasars are presented from Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (filled black circles, Bayesian constraints), along with their joint constraint at the average chromatic variation of their sample (light blue filled circle). Three quasars from this work are shown (red stars, <em>s</em> = 0.80), with a vertical red line marking the degree of chromatic variation in the fourth (RXJ 0911+0551, where we obtain no constraint). The red dashed line marks the power-law index <em>p</em> = 4/3, appropriate for the standard SS disc.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=I0msY9J3XiWoVewWgbw~DetWNd5Cv97f~AuYOn5wJD-8FoIOUlXINRUNc2H-6SEyElNMcFD707C1Jm1OAiuD5wuCRfH4pR1ZfsgPov7piLJ5cGAA~DFgE8PiLZFTJCeqB4xXkYFDzTHRsfgIIWh-R2fFx4~VE1yKPH0NPuv~Iz8kyMnDCwCiGxH~5gr7WnJ-4bnn8wNd7-sQtx8iUzdiJQboZN5JJDdKoq4VLrUzzYLp1-cbhbVI5MoMuhJnfxbQ5QnYxHpnExPyk8-qY-ntvaJYanIUw-C3mkMP6kOy0TLNlSC7yk41FiTmf87NNht8TvvNA6kMX8WyEjHDRLkkDw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Power-law constraints p (68 per cent confidence) as a function of the size of chromatic variation in the observation. As the degree of chromatic variation increases, so does the measured constraint on the power-law index. Seven quasars are presented from Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (2014) (filled black circles, Bayesian constraints), along with their joint constraint at the average chromatic variation of their sample (light blue filled circle). Three quasars from this work are shown (red stars, s = 0.80), with a vertical red line marking the degree of chromatic variation in the fourth (RXJ 0911+0551, where we obtain no constraint). The red dashed line marks the power-law index p = 4/3, appropriate for the standard SS disc.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991323/sty1793fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991323\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=yVuy4Ep798hkKqoUVQlnbZ5x3RWftjfw9JckpzjD9xzpnQbZCkl5uc4dr1JTuorakAJteqRLPOTBdH--u09Z3fKLKiLCfWVwZUHU8wIWnH3g2VbEO2LjPV3-fHN1uRsYEqni~7oftJ0b0EVNbaykkkoa7cp4eHN8J3UrmLuMMSUqb~BeTlWPht6yJnPME5hfEIUfEMf0j8HgyetikWg6WM05YZGfAlQ6qmWK8X2pqFtO5MwA7FoevuYkagkGMvE2jhZWYPR-z3Vu-VLzN2B3xXvLh-4B-HuOcIFIZoRdfxBMsRiBEIxbq~BryPZmU79mTZv6IOBmMsbFd4UxfLwfxQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991323&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Power-law constraints <em>p</em> (68 per cent confidence) as a function of the size of chromatic variation in the observation. As the degree of chromatic variation increases, so does the measured constraint on the power-law index. Seven quasars are presented from Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (filled black circles, Bayesian constraints), along with their joint constraint at the average chromatic variation of their sample (light blue filled circle). Three quasars from this work are shown (red stars, <em>s</em> = 0.80), with a vertical red line marking the degree of chromatic variation in the fourth (RXJ 0911+0551, where we obtain no constraint). The red dashed line marks the power-law index <em>p</em> = 4/3, appropriate for the standard SS disc.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming this trend is real, is it due to the physical situation in each individual quasar? Do the quasars where we observe lower chromatic variation actually have steeper temperature profiles in their accretion discs? Or is it simply a (misleading) selection effect, where observations with low chromatic variation lead us to believe we are observing a steeper temperature profile than actually exists in the quasar? We can check this with mock simulations, where we test how well we are able to recover a known input accretion disc using our single-epoch microlensing analysis technique. We analyse a sample suite of mock simulations below.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991325 id=\"118991325\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 MOCK OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To explore whether the correlation between size of the observed chromatic variation and the slope of the measured temperature profile is real or simply a selection effect, we generated a suite of 200 mock observations for a single input accretion disc. These were conducted in a blind fashion \u2013 one of us (GV) produced the mock data, and provided it as a set of magnitude differences to another (NFB), who ran them through the microlensing analysis pipeline. The purpose of these mock observations was twofold: (1) to test whether observations with low chromatic variation produce accretion disc constraints biased towards low <em>p</em>, and (2) to test whether any observations recover the input disc parameters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991327 id=\"118991327\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-1>7.1 Mock observation technique</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The same machinery was used to produce the mock observations as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>. We used equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ1\"></span><a href=\"#equ1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>) to create a series of Gaussian profiles to describe the shape of the accretion disc for each observed wavelength in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, with the parameters <em>p</em> = 1.5 and <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> = 2.7 light-days. We did this using the MG 0414+0534 macromodel, and the magnification maps we have already generated. For simplicity, we assumed the magnification for image <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> to be constant and equal to the macromagnification. We then selected a map with a fixed <em>s</em> for image <em>A</em><sub>2</sub>, convolved it with the generated source profiles, and sampled magnification values from the central 6700\u00a0\u00d7 6700\u00a0pixel area. This area was chosen in order to avoid convolution edge effects; the largest source profile, for observed wavelength \u03bb = 15369\u2009\u00c5, corresponds to roughly 3300 pixels in the source plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We used <em>s</em> = 0.8 and <em>s</em> = 0.9 magnification maps to generate the mock data, drawing 100 mock observations from each map. These smooth matter fractions are consistent with the values we expect to find in a real MG 0414+0534-like quasar. Using two smooth matter fractions allowed us to generate more statistically independent mock observations, and also to test whether the choice of <em>s</em> had an effect on our results. Unsurprisingly, we found that it did not \u2013 the two cases were indistinguishable.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout, we have assumed errors on our mock observations of \u00b10.05 in the UVIS channel, and \u00b10.02 in the IR channel. These are consistent with our <em>HST</em> observations. Although simulated magnitude differences were generated for nine <em>HST</em> filters (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), we used only five for the microlensing analysis: F410M (4109\u00c5), F621M (6219\u00c5), F845M (8436\u00c5), F125W (12486\u00c5), and F160W (15369\u00c5).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991331 id=\"118991331\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-2>7.2 Mock observation results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of single-epoch microlensing analysis on our mock observations are presented in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> (source size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>) and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> (power-law index <em>p</em>), plotted as a function of chromatic variation <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min}$|\u2060</span>. We have chosen to plot only the simulation results where we assumed a smooth matter fraction of <em>s</em> = 0.8 in the analysis pipeline; we also ran the microlensing simulations marginalizing over all smooth matter fractions, and found all of the same trends.</p>                        <a id=\"118991333\" scrollto-destination=\"118991333\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=LqB7a6mME9czFtmdEtkeDTqq7xgP8XHI~AjWMXeOqt2EM14QRyu4lnGipKQW7ebplM821EkBPArIXiiKKOM4zBYBB5~esPBEkC~uHXlRoJcGkHpRupVb7quxnYgxwHYSnFuPfdAXiReK2ssiQ7YJ~mX3ATRzF9swqHhD0j6kG0i4xW6XoVIUz3xtE9Fvoa9jaPHivd~yNDF3cBhAQzDDXcN5tEFu0JtcAoQS5sbuRVBTaS2l6pbD2DCtkynWdT7oyQeSru73vFN0YKqDwiaPliBchqs0WhmP2gb6hkZoM00ZL91jPW92eD80Mz73Bqu-VFdMF3BP5xlWo7dzh-antA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Quasar accretion disc size constraints rs as a function of the size of chromatic variation in mock observations. Grey points indicate individual measurements for 193 mock observations (error bars excluded for clarity). The dashed red line is the input value of rs = 2.7 light-days. Black crosses are the result of combining all likelihood surfaces in chromatic variation bins with a width of 0.1 (the number of mock observations in each bin is shown across the top of the figure). All error bars are 68 per cent confidence intervals; arrows indicate 68 per cent upper limits.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991333/sty1793fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991333\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=VOqIQJdM4hz--koGwtla8-IXvehnpp0qNgrDpi6ZR45OhVE1KN1kgj-BByq-gpg4m7bZjCiHyj-dkStwFA8lFmLqbPbm2HZQPFN4y6NuewEa40Uqxvb7dkLkMPACb9UflFyS-L-Zn5Y~iPdcp9nbZqLxAfV0yIVQIMzi-zxS0WjyIboPTfteK7N9XfMF26Y9gOhbFWXcgilrDut4VokJUR82g406KFOJLo8vuh3Ov2RelkjrZRw2QxrAzMsL90rFMJGOWMu2PK~4feM4UCNVaOMLPzZasUlySOj3-F~bPetJ~l8Awt1--9tYA53AmMyBPuR0CQMDYPm1HZ5AG7631Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991333&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Quasar accretion disc size constraints <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> as a function of the size of chromatic variation in mock observations. All error bars are 68 per cent confidence intervals; arrows indicate 68 per cent upper limits.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"118991334\" scrollto-destination=\"118991334\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=XyuzOKHHGTilC9aR7GVN6PnAo24CMDfoJ-SQbb~Lc5RKIg88FK-VZPMjkYOgR390SDZiXOTm~mKDtJA3ulst3t6Zn5iOyp~tTNOXEGmkX0Z3Dbo92SKqQG43--0DV82uDp~BUQ3q7-KWi-On0jSPp8phgSVlUPZ1ZM7cac2HvcNQpCVplNo3~wfm8DyyCYxynLkb~lYX0OEOTPXzUbkUTmfn-aiNkKtCcpQM21r3h05l4wjZPLTbMhrGLZzFjvXp6WUe4BreSdmhk09z9tIy6jFhfyV0UvM7D67MsbYomdYzmOwseIUCrLcZgzrki9EqF~f9atbs4NMUG~PyVbr37A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Power-law temperature profile constraints p as a function of the size of chromatic variation in mock observations.
