$(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n </i>\r\n            Permissions\r\n        </a>\r\n    </div>\r\n \n    </div>\n\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-share              <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nEccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li           <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f479%2f4%2f4796%2f5050072\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n       <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991217 id=\"118991217\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present new <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> WFC3 imaging of four gravitationally lensed quasars: MG 0414+0534; RXJ 0911+0551; B 1422+231; WFI J2026-4536. In three of these systems we detect wavelength-dependent microlensing, which we use to place constraints on the sizes and temperature profiles of the accretion discs in each quasar. Accretion disc radius is assumed to vary with wavelength according to the power-law relationship <em>r</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0\u03bb<sup><em>p</em></sup>, equivalent to a radial temperature profile of <em>T</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>r</em><sup>\u22121/<em>p</em></sup>. The goal of this work is to search for deviations from standard thin disc theory, which predicts that radius goes as wavelength to the power <em>p</em> = 4/3. We find a wide range of power-law indices, from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p=1.4^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span> in B 1422+231to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p=2.3^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span> in WFI J2026-4536. The measured value of <em>p</em> appears to correlate with the strength of the wavelength-dependent microlensing. We explore this issue with mock simulations using a fixed accretion disc with <em>p</em> = 1.5, and find that cases where wavelength-dependent microlensing is small tend to underestimate the value of <em>p</em>. This casts doubt on previous ensemble single-epoch measurements which have favoured low values using samples of lensed quasars that display only moderate chromatic effects. Using only our systems with strong chromatic microlensing we prefer <em>p</em> &gt; 4/3, corresponding to shallower temperature profiles than expected from standard thin disc theory.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;accretion, accretion discs&quot;\">accretion, accretion discs</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: micro&quot;\">gravitational lensing: micro</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: MG 0414+0534&quot;\">quasars: individual: MG 0414+0534</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: RXJ 0911+0551&quot;\">quasars: individual: RXJ 0911+0551</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: B 1422+231&quot;\">quasars: individual: B 1422+231</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: WFI J2026-4536&quot;\">quasars: individual: WFI J2026-4536</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991219 id=\"118991219\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations of gravitationally microlensed quasars offer a unique opportunity to study the structure of quasar accretion discs at rest frame ultraviolet (UV) and optical wavelengths. These analyses hinge on the fact that gravitational lensing is achromatic, but the magnitude of any microlensing-induced brightness fluctuations depends strongly on the projected size of the emission region in the lensed source. In a quasar accretion disc, hotter regions are expected to be physically smaller than cooler regions, and so will be more strongly magnified by microlensing.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Microlensing analyses have already thrown up challenges to the standard thin disc theory. It has been robustly established that quasar accretion discs in the observed optical (2500 \u00c5 rest frame) are larger by factors of 2 to 4 than expected. This result is obtained from both single-epoch observations, and light-curve analyses. In the latter case (e.g. Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; the review of Chartas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a> and references therein), observationally expensive monitoring campaigns are conducted to gather microlensing light curves, typically focused on accretion disc sizes at single, or occasionally two, wavelengths (usually X-ray and optical). Single-epoch studies (e.g. Pooley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Blackburne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) allow for easier analysis of larger samples of objects, and return similar results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">When multiwavelength data are available, quasar microlensing observations can be used to map the radial profile of the accretion disc as a function of wavelength (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Eigenbrod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Floyd, Bate &amp; Webster <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Blackburne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Blackburne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Rojas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Typically, a power-law of the form <em>r</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0\u03bb<sup><em>p</em></sup> is assumed. The standard Shakura &amp; Sunyaev (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1973</a>) disc sets <em>p</em> = 4/3 (hereafter SS), but other models predict different values for <em>p</em> (e.g. Abramowicz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>, <em>p</em> = 2.0; Agol &amp; Krolik <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>, <em>p</em> = 8/7).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Under the assumption that the emergent accretion disc spectrum is the superposition of blackbody spectra generated locally in the disc, the spectral profile <em>r</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0\u03bb<sup><em>p</em></sup> is related to the temperature profile via the power-law index <em>p</em>: <em>T</em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>r</em><sup>\u22121/<em>p</em></sup> (see e.g. Frank, King &amp; Raine <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Constraints on the power-law index of the spectral profile are therefore also constraints on the radial temperature profile. If <em>p</em> &gt; 4/3, temperature falls off as a function of radius more slowly than expected from the SS disc (a shallower temperature profile). If <em>p</em> &lt; 4/3, the temperature profile is steeper and cools down more rapidly with radius than the SS disc .</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Early temperature profile measurements using microlensing have painted a conflicting picture. Single-epoch observations of microlensed accretion discs seem to favour steeper temperature profiles than SS (<em>p</em> &lt; 4/3, e.g. Floyd et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Blackburne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Mu\u00f1oz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), although there are exceptions (e.g. Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Rojas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This is difficult to reconcile with measurements of larger than expected discs at optical wavelengths, since a steeper temperature profile implies that the accretion disc will be smaller at a given wavelength, not larger.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Most temperature profile measurements have been performed on single systems, or occasionally a handful. The most recent ensemble measurement is Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, who analysed 10 image pairs in eight lensed quasars. They found a joint Bayesian estimate for the power-law index of <em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2 at 68\u2009per\u2009cent confidence, well below the fiducial <em>p</em> = 4/3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational microlensing is currently the only technique that has been used to study the physical structure of these objects at high redshifts (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01.5\u20133.5). Photometric reverberation mapping has been used to probe accretion discs in lower-redshift active galactic nuclei (AGNs). The AGN Space Telescope and Optical Reverberation Mapping project has examined the accretion disc in the Seyfert NGC 5548 in considerable detail (see especially Fausnaugh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Starkey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), using 19 overlapping continuum light curves to measure a larger size and steeper temperature profile (<em>p</em> = 1.01 \u00b1 0.03) in that system. A similarly detailed analysis of NGC 4593 (Cackett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) also found a larger than expected size, but the measured temperature profile was consistent with the standard thin disc prescription. Jiang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) analysed a sample of 240 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.1\u20130.3 quasars from Pan-STARRS. They again measure larger accretion disc sizes than expected from thin-disc theory, however they favour flatter temperature profiles (with the caveat that their wavelength coverage is much shorter than the Starkey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a> or Cackett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a> analyses).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Understanding the diversity of temperature profile measurements, along with the apparent contradiction between larger discs and (possibly) steeper temperature profiles requires more data, and careful consideration of sources of error and contamination in both our observations and our analysis techniques. The principle contaminants in single-epoch observations are: time delays between lensed images causing us to catch the background quasar in different underlying states; broad emission lines that fall in broad-band filters and dilute the signal from the quasar continuum; and differential extinction. Possible systematic effects have been poorly explored.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present multiwavelength <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) observations of four gravitationally lensed quasars: MG 0414+0534 (Hewitt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>), RXJ 0911+0551 (Bade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), B 1422+231 (Patnaik et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>), and WFI J2026-4536 (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). These observations were tuned to mitigate some of the major challenges and sources of uncertainty facing multiband single-epoch imaging analyses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we discuss issues around our sample selection, including common contaminants in single-epoch microlensing analyses. We also present background detail on the four lensed quasars studied here, summarizing any existing microlensing analyses. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we present our data, and describe the reduction process. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we lay out our simulation technique. First, we discuss macrolens models for each of our systems, then the single-epoch microlensing analysis technique. This technique broadly follows <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> but differs in a few key details. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>, we present the results of our analysis, and then discuss their implications in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. This discussion leads to a suite of mock observations in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>, which clarify the origin of the steep temperature profiles measured in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>. Finally, we conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">8</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper, we use a cosmology with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0 = 72\\ \\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}\\ \\rm {Mpc}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _{\\rm m} = 0.3$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda = 0.7$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991231 id=\"118991231\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 SAMPLE SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we discuss common issues relating to the single-epoch imaging technique, including methods for their mitigation. We then present our <em>HST</em> sample of four gravitationally lensed quasars, and briefly discuss any previous microlensing analyses of these systems.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991233 id=\"118991233\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Single-epoch imaging technique contaminants</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Single-epoch imaging studies of quasar microlensing are subject to a number of potential contaminants, which have been successfully handled to a greater or lesser degree. The principle contaminants in the observations are: (i) time delays between lensed images; (ii) broad emission lines that fall in broad-band filters and dilute the signal from the quasar continuum; and (iii) differential extinction. Finally, (iv) possible systematic effects in our analysis technique have been poorly explored. We will discuss each of these issues in turn, focussing on how we have mitigated them in the current analysis. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Quasars are variable on all time-scales longer than a day (MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and so time delays between lensed images can mean that the background quasar is captured in a different state in each image with a single observation. In order to eliminate quasar variability as a source of contamination, we work only with close image pairs. In these cases, time delays are expected to be short (less than a day), and so we can be confident that the quasar is in the same state in each image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Close image pairs provide an ideal laboratory for microlensing constraints on quasar accretion discs (Bate, Webster &amp; Wyithe <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Floyd et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). In the presence of a high smooth matter fraction \u2013 expected in the outskirts of lensing galaxies, where lensed quasar images typically form \u2013 one of the close images (the saddle point image) is preferentially suppressed by microlensing (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Vernardos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This frequently leads to a large magnification difference between the close images, which produce the tightest single-epoch accretion disc size constraints. It is often overlooked that, conversely, small magnification differences between lensed images provide very little information on accretion disc sizes (see fig. 4 in Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With their &lt;0.5\u2009arcsec separation, deblending of close image pairs is a significant challenge with ground-based imaging. For this reason, the photometric precision afforded by <em>HST</em> is essential.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measurements of the continuum slope with broad multiband photometry risk line contamination, which arises due to differing physical scales for broad line and continuum emission in the source quasar. Since broad lines are expected to be emitted from larger physical scales than the continuum, they will be affected by microlensing differently (see e.g. Abajas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Wayth, O\u2019Dowd &amp; Webster <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; O\u2019Dowd et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sluse et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>). If a broad-band filter overlaps a broad emission line, the flux you observe in that filter is therefore a combination of broad line and continuum emission, and so convolves microlensing information on two physical scales.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Line contamination can be avoided with sufficient spectral resolution. However, this does not necessitate full spectroscopy. Narrow- or medium-band filters can be chosen to cleanly select regions of the quasar spectrum free from broad line contamination (e.g. Mosquera et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). This approach grants higher signal to noise for a given exposure time than spectroscopy, and also greatly simplifies the deblending of close lensed image pairs. This is the approach we have chosen, using medium-band <em>HST</em> filters to minimize the impact of broad emission lines on our results.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Differential extinction can produce chromatic variation that mimics the effects of microlensing (see e.g. O\u2019Dowd et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). This can be effectively removed by monitoring the system and conducting light-curve analyses: differential extinction is not expected to vary on microlensing-like time-scales.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Accounting for it in single-epoch observations is much harder. In the ideal case, we would have observations of regions in the quasar that are sufficiently large to be unaffected by microlensing, emitting at wavelengths very similar to the continuum, to establish the baseline impact of differential extinction. For example, Mediavilla et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> use the narrow component of broad emission lines to estimate intrinsic flux ratios. In the absence of adequate spectroscopy, infrared or radio flux ratios can be used to estimate intrinsic magnification ratios. This is the method we adopt here.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The final issue is systematics in our simulation technique, and it remains relatively unexplored. Single-epoch analyses have proceeded under the assumption that the simulations provide a clean measurement of the structure of the quasar accretion disc, if contaminants in the observational data are minimized. In this paper, we will present the first evidence that this assumption may not be strictly true.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This last issue will be particularly important in the forthcoming synoptic survey era. Currently, we have temperature profile measurements for only a handful of lensed quasars; only\u00a0\u223c100 are known (see Mosquera &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a> for a compilation). The Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST; LSST Science Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) alone is expected to discover thousands more (Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), enabling studies of true statistical samples. Future surveys may provide us with light curves of these systems, superseding the single-epoch technique. However, the time-scales for microlensing variations are often years or decades, and so there will still be a use for single-epoch analyses for the foreseeable future.</p></li></ul></p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991235 id=\"118991235\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 <em>HST</em> sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The four lensed systems studied here were specifically chosen from a larger programme to have no obvious ring features in our data. The presence of full or partial Einstein rings indicates that the quasar host galaxy is being significantly lensed. Rings or arcs provide more constraints for modelling the lens, however they may be an additional source of contamination in any measured flux ratios between lensed images. This issue will be explored in more detail in subsequent papers.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991237 id=\"118991237\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-1>2.2.1 MG 0414+0534</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system, first reported in Hewitt et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>), has been the subject of a significant number of lensing analyses. This is in part due to an anomaly in the flux ratio between images <em>A</em><sub>2</sub> and <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> that persists into the infrared and the radio. This has been taken to indicate the presence of unobserved substructure in the lens, on so-called millilensing scales (approximately dwarf galaxy-sized, see e.g. Mao &amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek &amp; Dalal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Pooley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), the authors used X-ray and optical data to study the relative sizes of the accretion discs in 10 systems, including MG 0414+0534. They found that the optical continuum emission in this quasar arose from a region\u00a0\u223c3\u00a0times larger than expected from thin disc theory. Blackburne et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) followed up this analysis by also constraining the temperature profile of the accretion disc, finding a value consistent with the SS <em>p</em> = 4/3 scaling. It is worth noting that this result was at odds with all of the other systems in their paper, for which they found very low values of <em>p</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2. An X-ray microlensing size measurement of MG 0414+0534 also appears in Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have also previously studied the accretion disc in MG 0414+0534 (Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Although the errors in our previous analysis were large, we found an accretion disc temperature profile formally consistent with the SS disc at the 2\u03c3 level, with a preference for power-law indices <em>p</em> &gt; 4/3 (formal constraint: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.6^{+0.6}_{-0.5}$|</span> at 68 per cent confidence). Our analysis was conducted with an earlier version of the single-epoch imaging technique, which did not account for errors in macromodelling. Given the possible presence of substructure near the A<sub>2</sub>/A<sub>1</sub> image pair, this omission may be significant.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991241 id=\"118991241\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-2>2.2.2 RXJ 0911+0551</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">RXJ 0911+0551 is an X-ray bright lensed quasar originally detected in the <em>ROSAT</em> All-Sky Survey (Bade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). It has appeared in the X-ray accretion disc analyses of Pooley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), Blackburne et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), and Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>). In Pooley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), the quasar was found to have an optical accretion disc size\u00a0\u223c6\u00a0times larger than expected from thin disc theory.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using optical, IR, and X-ray data, Blackburne et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) reported a temperature profile for this system consistent with no wavelength dependence (<em>p</em> = 0.17 \u00b1 0.41). These particularly low values of <em>p</em> (corresponding to steep temperature profiles) were the overall result for their analysis of 12 systems.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991244 id=\"118991244\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-3>2.2.3 B 1422+231</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">B 1422+231 (Patnaik et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>) is also part of the Pooley et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) sample of lensed quasars. It differs from MG 0414+0534 in that its optical size measurement is apparently consistent with thin disc theory. It is also included in the joint size analyses of Mediavilla et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>), and Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>) (the first three using optical data, the latter X-ray), but to date no temperature profile measurement has been reported.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mao &amp; Schneider (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) used anomalies in the radio flux ratios to argue for the presence of substructure in the lens. This was the first time that this use for lensed quasar observations was explicitly discussed in the literature. Our lens models are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>; for this system, we make no attempt to account for millilensing substructure.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991247 id=\"118991247\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-4>2.2.4 WFI J2026-4536</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WFI J2026-4536 is the most recently discovered system in this paper (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and has only appeared in one microlensing accretion disc analysis: Blackburne et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). They again found an extremely steep temperature profile, consistent with no wavelength dependence (<em>p</em> = 0.27 \u00b1 0.53).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) reported that WFI J2026-4536is a problematic system to model. This will be discussed further in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>. The system\u2019s lens redshift is currently unknown.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991250 id=\"118991250\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations were taken in <em>HST</em> Cycle 20 (Program ID 12874, PI Floyd). Imaging was performed with <em>HST</em>\u2019s Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) in both the UVIS and IR channels, utilizing four to seven medium-band filters for each target. Medium-band imaging allows us to select filters that fall between broad emission lines. This is important because the broad emission line region is much larger than the accretion disc and so experiences different microlensing magnification (when it is microlensed at all). The suite of WFC3 medium band filters allows us to avoid these lines at all source redshifts. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the example case of WFI J2026-4536: filter transmission curves are overlaid on a composite quasar spectrum (Vanden Berk et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) at this quasar\u2019s redshift. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> details exposure times, dates, and filters for each source.</p>                        <a id=\"118991252\" scrollto-destination=\"118991252\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=niz35pa9NIn8TSXjMJ-IFdhbxOxES4NHPzYr49PRL1t-Dv6Z0004V2xrHJjBN-vvsHHuY7Nz75MTb2Nl5KzlaNHzGqZb~Ux-dbuvFRscJHjGf0i248hnzYQcQ4jsE990u6MNuKmecasM2xjcgd344qzwcon67CZ6p3jCRt3RdJsPVXm6KP~TTG78aQQU4WFoUYa1BNKu-9MWTlR0rm8Is5MhcSgFUiCAUq8~dzNa3pudUMOzMwguMr33M66ufFVfuXhMcHUVgJF2X2~BmmceJHmDauotsvpnCAlkuNLpdravCz2bY9NP0YlPk3GMM8ymwpYicJY4WQ9QMTj2tqJpNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST WFC3 filter transmission curves, overlaid on a quasar composite spectrum (Vanden Berk et\u00a0al. 2001) at the redshift of WFI J2026-4536($z$ = 2.23). This illustrates how we have used medium-band filters to select regions between broad emission lines, to avoid contaminating the signal from the microlensed accretion disc.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991252/sty1793fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991252\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=rrwvJhOLOYbL-iNGE7RbmQvxFIq-LZG7XHcouNLxkBmVvHsi5RdoDdc7cOg-JI9LwPepFkvietCXRTgBdc949XbyW6DDhm5T7BKOIgj~vySV6szLaUzZ-2H9lq63ZCBdFPnVAvBROyMbMdd6squRvRdVhZLMsaRIjC99cbx-2oF6dVs4uL9epQ4bzwmpMZ1gj9mEaWWuZXlT8lq68v8vnaEeoxLNei-i0fLv~p1VNjLC14E8oPeMeo3y3drSktPzNihZF4q7uLiLGkABx6G39T1gIUn~rMctOoiMkJC0N~TGI4S6VFMwvsaOFiCPYeJlZwlkfSzRTawSydMLdp8-jw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991252&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> WFC3 filter transmission curves, overlaid on a quasar composite spectrum (Vanden Berk et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) at the redshift of WFI J2026-4536(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span> = 2.23). This illustrates how we have used medium-band filters to select regions between broad emission lines, to avoid contaminating the signal from the microlensed accretion disc.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=niz35pa9NIn8TSXjMJ-IFdhbxOxES4NHPzYr49PRL1t-Dv6Z0004V2xrHJjBN-vvsHHuY7Nz75MTb2Nl5KzlaNHzGqZb~Ux-dbuvFRscJHjGf0i248hnzYQcQ4jsE990u6MNuKmecasM2xjcgd344qzwcon67CZ6p3jCRt3RdJsPVXm6KP~TTG78aQQU4WFoUYa1BNKu-9MWTlR0rm8Is5MhcSgFUiCAUq8~dzNa3pudUMOzMwguMr33M66ufFVfuXhMcHUVgJF2X2~BmmceJHmDauotsvpnCAlkuNLpdravCz2bY9NP0YlPk3GMM8ymwpYicJY4WQ9QMTj2tqJpNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST WFC3 filter transmission curves, overlaid on a quasar composite spectrum (Vanden Berk et\u00a0al. 2001) at the redshift of WFI J2026-4536($z$ = 2.23).    .\u00a0</span></th><th>WFC3/IR<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG 0414+0534\u00a0</td><td>2.64\u00a0</td><td>0.96\u00a0</td><td>2013-07-25\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>F763M F845M\u00a0</td><td>F125W F160W\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ 0911+0551\u00a0</td><td>2.80\u00a0</td><td>0.77\u00a0</td><td>2012-10-19\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>F547M F621M F689M F845M\u00a0</td><td>F125W F160W\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td>3.62\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0</td><td>2013-07-12\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>F621M F763M F845M\u00a0</td><td>F105W F125W F160W\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>2.23\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>2012-11-22\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>F410M F547M F689M F763M F845M\u00a0</td><td>F125W F160W\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991253\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Data were reduced using the standard <em>HST</em> Astrodrizzle reduction pipeline. Fluxes of individual lensed images were measured using GALFIT (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) to fit a point spread function (PSF) at the location of each lensed image, while the lensing galaxy was fit with a Sersic profile. Free parameters in the fit included lensed image and lensing galaxy fluxes as well as positions of all sources. TinyTim (Krist, Hook &amp; Stoehr <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) was used to generate WFC3 PSFs, and StarFit (Timothy Hamilton, private communication) was used to propagate these PSFs through the dither-combine pipeline to match the final combined PSFs. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> gives the measured magnitudes for all lensed images and lensing galaxies.</p>                        <a id=\"118991255\" scrollto-destination=\"118991255\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl7\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl7\" data-id=\"tbl7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed Vega magnitudes of all lensed images and lensing galaxies.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Not detected in our data.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991255\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, we present observed magnitude differences for the image pairs of interest (typically the close image pair). The observed wavelengths are taken to be the pivot wavelengths of each filter. These are the data that are used for the microlensing analysis presented in this paper.</p>                        <a id=\"118991257\" scrollto-destination=\"118991257\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl8\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl8\" data-id=\"tbl8\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed magnitude differences used in the current microlensing analysis.</p></div> </div><div \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991257\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991258 id=\"118991258\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 MODELLING AND SIMULATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe the various components of our lens modelling and microlensing simulation technique.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991260 id=\"118991260\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Lens models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Models of the lensing potentials in each system provide us with the key parameters for microlensing simulations: the convergence \u03ba and shear \u03b3 at each lensed image position.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991262 id=\"118991262\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-1>4.1.1 MG 0414+0534</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MG 0414+0534 is known to harbour substructure in the vicinity of the anomalous <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>A</em><sub>2</sub> image pair. Simple lens models consisting only of a singular isothermal ellipse and external shear do not reproduce the <em>A</em><sub>2</sub>/<em>A</em><sub>1</sub> flux ratios observed in the radio and mid-IR (e.g Katz, Moore &amp; Hewitt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Minezaki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). MacLeod et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) used these data to search for the best-fitting location for a dark substructure near the anomalous image pair. They found a best-fitting mass of 10<sup>6.2</sup>M<sub><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\odot$|</span></sub> to 10<sup>7.5</sup>M<sub><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\odot$|</span></sub>, located to the north-east of image <em>A</em><sub>2</sub> (modelled as a singular isothermal sphere at the redshift of the lensing galaxy).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We take the MacLeod et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) G1+G2+G3 model using both mid-IR and radio data (see their Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, repeated here in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>), and calculate convergences and shears at the <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>A</em><sub>2</sub> image positions using <span class=\"small-caps\">lensmodel</span><sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> (Keeton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). This model includes three lenses: the primary lens galaxy G1, a secondary nearby (observed) galaxy G2, and the (dark) substructure G3 discussed in the previous paragraph. The microlensing parameters for this model are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118991265\" scrollto-destination=\"118991265\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Microlensing parameters, convergence \u03ba, and shear \u03b3.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>System<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03ba<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03ba<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b3<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Source<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>MG 0414+0534\u00a0</td><td><em>A</em><sub>1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.51\u00a0</td><td>0.42\u00a0</td><td><em>A</em><sub>2</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.56\u00a0</td><td>0.51\u00a0</td><td>MacLeod et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>651\u00a0</td><td>0.133\u00a0</td><td>\u221225.0\u00a0</td><td>0.133\u00a0</td><td>82.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>This work\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991266\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table 5. .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>b</em><sub>3</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>x</em><sub>3</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td>0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>74\u00a0</td><td>0.39\u00a0</td><td>\u221258.9\u00a0</td><td>0.137\u00a0</td><td>\u221247.2\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Schechter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td>0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>651\u00a0</td><td>0.133\u00a0</td><td>\u221225.0\u00a0</td><td>0.133\u00a0</td><td>82.9\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>This work\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991266\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991267 id=\"118991267\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-2>4.1.2 RXJ 0911+0551<em>and</em> B 1422+231</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For RXJ 0911+0551 and B 1422+231, we use lens models from the literature (Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). These models consist of a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) with an orientation and ellipticity constrained to match the observed shape of the stellar component in each lensing galaxy, plus an external shear term (referred to as SIE+X or SIE+\u03b3 models). The RXJ 0911+0551model also includes a secondary lens at the position of an observed smudge in the system, modelled as a singular isothermal sphere (Blackburne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The model parameters are reproduced in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> for convenience, and their resulting convergences and shears are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991269 id=\"118991269\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-3>4.1.3 WFI J2026-4536</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">WFI J2026-4536 is a slightly more complicated case. Both Chantry, Sluse &amp; Magain (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>) found this system difficult to fit accurately with simple lens models. In Chantry et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), they chose to constrain the ellipticity and position angle of an SIE+X lens model by the light (similar to the models in Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Imposing these constraints resulted in a large formal \u03c7<sup>2</sup>; models with a significant offset between the position angles of the mass and the light were preferred. In Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>), they relaxed these constraints and also added a second mass component to describe a nearby galaxy. In this case they again preferred models where the mass and light are significantly misaligned, possibly hinting at the presence of dark substructures.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In light of these complications, we opted to generate a simple SIE+X model where we left the orientation and the ellipticity of the lens as free parameters. We kept the position of the lens fixed to the centre of the light profile, and used only the image positions as constraints. The best-fitting model, generated with the <span class=\"small-caps\">lensmodel</span> code, is provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. It is similar to the SIE+X case in Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>). We emphasize that this model should be considered illustrative; it does not include the full complexities of the system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The WFI J2026-4536 lens redshift is also currently unknown. To convert our measured sizes into physical parameters we adopt a lens redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>l</em>, 2026</sub> = 1.04, estimated from the image separations and probability distributions for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>l</em></sub> (Ofek, Rix &amp; Maoz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Mosquera &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991273 id=\"118991273\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Simulation technique</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We broadly follow the simulation technique laid out in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, with two important differences. The technique is described below, highlighting the areas where our methods differ. The basic outlines are <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Generate magnification maps from lens models.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Isolate the microlensing signal from macrolensing using infrared or radio observations.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Conduct Bayesian microlensing simulations to extract accretion disc parameters.</p></li></ul></p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991275 id=\"118991275\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-1>4.2.1 Magnification maps</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens models described in the previous section provide the two key microlensing parameters at the location of each lensed image: the convergence \u03ba and shear \u03b3 (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The convergence can be split into two components: a clumpy component \u03ba<sub>*</sub> that describes point-mass (stellar) microlenses, and a smooth component \u03ba<sub><em>s</em></sub>, such that \u03ba = \u03ba<sub>*</sub> + \u03ba<sub><em>s</em></sub>. The smooth matter fraction is <em>s</em> = \u03ba<sub><em>s</em></sub>/\u03ba.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the systems studied here, the lensed images lie in the outskirts of the lens galaxies, so we expect the smooth matter fraction to be high. Typical values obtained from previous microlensing analyses range from smooth matter fractions of\u00a0\u223c80 per cent (e.g Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>) to\u00a0\u223c93 per cent (e.g. Pooley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> took the smooth matter fraction to be 95 per cent in their analysis; we chose instead to vary it. We used 11 smooth matter fractions <em>s</em> = 0.0, 0.1, 0.2, \u2026, 0.9, 0.99, and discuss the impact of smooth matter fraction on our results below. This is the first key difference between our analysis and that of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnification maps were generated using the GPU-D code (Thompson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Bate &amp; Fluke <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), within the GERLUMPH framework (Vernardos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Vernardos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We used maps with a side length of 100 Einstein radii, and 10\u2009000 pixels, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm micro} = 1\\text{M}_{\\odot }$|</span> microlenses. This corresponds to physical per-pixel resolutions of 0.1445 (MG 0414+0534), 0.1618 (RXJ 0911+0551), 0.2207 (B 1422+231), and 0.1341 (WFI J2026-4536) light-days. This resolution is\u00a0\u223c0.5\u00a0times the innermost stable circular orbit of a 10<sup>9</sup>M<sub><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\odot$|</span></sub> black hole, sufficient for our rest-frame UV to optical observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All physical sizes quoted in this paper depend on the choice of microlens mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm micro}$|\u2060</span>, so all physical units can be rescaled by a factor of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(M_{\\rm micro}/M_{\\odot })^{1/2}$|\u2060</span>. We omit this factor from scales throughout this paper for readability, but it should be assumed to be present in every physical measurement obtained via microlensing simulations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All magnification maps are available for download via the GERLUMPH website.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup></p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991281 id=\"118991281\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2-2>4.2.2 Isolating the microlensing signal</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We conduct our microlensing simulations using the magnitude differences <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm obs} = m_B - m_A$|</span> (or <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m_{A_2} - m_{A_1}$|</span> as appropriate) provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We note that the simulations can trivially be run in terms of flux ratio instead, as in our previous papers (Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Floyd et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), using the relationship <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm obs} = m_B - m_A = -2.5\\rm {log}_{10}(f_B/f_A)$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In an ideal case, we would isolate the microlensing signal from both macrolensing and differential extinction by using a series of \u0394<em>m</em> measurements from emission regions in the source large enough to be unaffected by microlensing. These emission regions would need to emit at similar wavelengths to the continuum source in order to accurately map the effects of extinction.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The procedure adopted by Mediavilla et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and following papers were to use the centres of broad emission lines in spectra to establish unmicrolensed baselines. We do not currently have access to suitable spectra for all of our systems, and in any case there is some question over the accuracy of the assumption that no microlensing is present in the centres of broad emission lines.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We chose instead to normalize all of our observed magnitude differences within a given system to a single unmicrolensed baseline: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm micro} = \\Delta m_{\\rm obs} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}$|\u2060</span>. The baseline <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}$|</span> is taken in the radio or infrared where possible, and removes only the effects of macrolensing. This is the second key difference between our analysis and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>. In practice, it means that we are attributing all of the chromatic variation in our observations to microlensing, and none to any other chromatic effects such as differential extinction. We note that since extinction can effect either image in a lensed pair, neglecting differential extinction could lead us to overestimate <em>or</em> underestimate the size of any chromatic microlensing.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The literature data used to determine unmicrolensed baselines are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. We can compare the observed baselines with the predictions from our lens models, to check for consistency. In two cases, MG 0414+0534 and B 1422+231, we find that our lens model values lie marginally outside the observed values. To account for this, we expand the errors on the unmicrolensed baselines used in our simulations. We do not have suitable observations for WFI J2026-4536, so we choose to assume that the lens model prediction for the unmicrolensed baseline is correct, but assign it a correspondingly large error (23 percent in the ratio). This value for the error was chosen conservatively: it is approximately twice the percentage error in the least-accurately measured unmicrolensed baseline in our sample (RXJ 0911+0551), and approximately twice the largest deviation between model predicted and observed values (B 1422+231).</p>                        <a id=\"118991287\" scrollto-destination=\"118991287\"></a>\r\n<div \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0GHz (Jackson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>\u2013<em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.08 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.20\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.08 \u00b1 0.12\u00a0</td><td>8.4\u00a0GHz (Patnaik et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI J2026-4536\u00a0</td><td><em>A</em><sub>2</sub>\u2013<em>A</em><sub>1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0</td><td>0.14 \u00b1 0.25\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118991287\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we provide the measured microlensing amplitudes <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm micro} = \\Delta m_{\\rm obs} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}$|</span> for each of our four systems. Here, we have simply added the errors in the unmicrolensed baseline (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, fifth column) to the observational errors in quadrature. We note that these errors are handled differently in our microlensing simulations, as they represent a systematic offset rather than an independent error in each data point. This will be described in detail in the next section. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> is provided to give a sense of the size of the microlensing signal in each system.</p>                        <a id=\"118991289\" scrollto-destination=\"118991289\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl9\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl9\" data-id=\"tbl9\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p \\, 0.25$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span \\, 0.12$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B 1422+231\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>\u2013<em>A</em>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-0.08\\, \\pm \\, class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.53\\, \\pm \\, 0.12$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.48\\, \\pm \\, 0.12$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span
