All error bars are 68 per cent confidence intervals; arrows indicate 68 per cent upper limits.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=XyuzOKHHGTilC9aR7GVN6PnAo24CMDfoJ-SQbb~Lc5RKIg88FK-VZPMjkYOgR390SDZiXOTm~mKDtJA3ulst3t6Zn5iOyp~tTNOXEGmkX0Z3Dbo92SKqQG43--0DV82uDp~BUQ3q7-KWi-On0jSPp8phgSVlUPZ1ZM7cac2HvcNQpCVplNo3~wfm8DyyCYxynLkb~lYX0OEOTPXzUbkUTmfn-aiNkKtCcpQM21r3h05l4wjZPLTbMhrGLZzFjvXp6WUe4BreSdmhk09z9tIy6jFhfyV0UvM7D67MsbYomdYzmOwseIUCrLcZgzrki9EqF~f9atbs4NMUG~PyVbr37A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Power-law temperature profile constraints p as a function of the size of chromatic variation in mock observations. Grey points indicate individual measurements for 193 mock observations (error bars excluded for clarity). The dashed red line is the input value of p = 1.5. Black crosses are the result of combining all likelihood surfaces in chromatic variation bins with a width of 0.1 (the number of mock observations in each bin is shown across the top of the figure). All error bars are 68 per cent confidence intervals; arrows indicate 68 per cent upper limits.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991334/sty1793fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991334\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=frA2MOy87uQRiLr0P9WnyrLJM3bmYbgQEheIL10dKBAKagD7~HAeC5l~M1V167HTWa7UYMhT33jFu6NT34~yIOTV1VHVFNlXeCKjiAEMuWCCsyVJCnN4TpiYCGmsO52X9BXWpafSBEJH19eaQpz8eI7FmQNUQDMvk5LZqJLhW~MpmWVL2i4DmIweHDPhBqsiuPxOUMa6uoY-b66reHiKY-6imBd32Yrya0BNaleIbt5JAVGZcX8OhLwtvK8JribGWuaP3Fmibn1gbmN8UtM4iaZmmOaLJaTrWf9ZQYa3qBPR7ywWltLZ9wRhwoW~ZjVCvT2ZUi6HXoSmiM~QV7EfuA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991334&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Power-law temperature profile constraints <em>p</em> as a function of the size of chromatic variation in mock observations. Grey points indicate individual measurements for 193 mock observations (error bars excluded for clarity). The dashed red line is the input value of <em>p</em> = 1.5. Black crosses are the result of combining all likelihood surfaces in chromatic variation bins with a width of 0.1 (the number of mock observations in each bin is shown across the top of the figure). All error bars are 68 per cent confidence intervals; arrows indicate 68 per cent upper limits.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The grey points in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> show the individual constraints for each of the mock simulations. The error bars on the individual simulations have been excluded for clarity. Errors on any single measurement are broad, corresponding roughly to the sizes of the observed constraints in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. A total of 193 points are plotted: seven mock observations returned no meaningful constraints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have also combined the likelihood surfaces in bins of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} = 0.1$|\u2060</span>, treating each mock observation as an independent observation of the same source. These combined results are plotted as black crosses with error bars in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>; across the top of each plot, we show the number of mock observations in each bin. Red dashed lines show the input parameters of <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> = 2.7 light-days and <em>p</em> = 1.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These illustrative mock simulations demonstrate exactly the trend seen in the observational data: smaller chromatic variation leads to smaller estimated power-law indices <em>p</em>. They also result in larger estimated source sizes <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>. We note that the simulations presented in Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) cover a range in chromatic variation of roughly <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.04 \\lt \\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.52$|\u2060</span>. The four quasars presented in this paper span the much larger range from 0.07 (RXJ 0911+0551) to 1.29 (WFI J2026-4536).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mock observations with chromatic variations larger than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} = 1.0$|</span> are rare; in most bins we have only one or a few simulated data points. There is some suggestion that we undershoot (overshoot) the input <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> (<em>p</em>) for sufficiently large chromatic variation, however more mock observations are required to robustly explore this part of parameter space.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nevertheless, it does appear that for chromatic variation above a certain threshold (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\approx 0.6$|\u2060</span>) we do recover the input simulation parameters relatively well. We find that we can improve our recovery rate by using only mock observations that roughly converge to the theoretically expected macromagnification in their reddest filter. Using a convergence criterion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro} \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>, we are able to push the threshold of useful data down to chromatic variations of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\approx 0.4$|\u2060</span>. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we plot the 110 mock observations that meet this convergence limit.</p>                        <a id=\"118991340\" scrollto-destination=\"118991340\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=1UPsHkST4xabypdxCCzXIbBcdhx5oStAC8X71tVe7X27hOUmN~v-~ao7AZNJQ3dmRCXoAOVJ58PT7eVqbrsTh8aoOrVWrkErvbgTEQOmKLENTNiJasuZRF0kkA8BUVXlMa9Js2qZ35uyqGJ4~Sww9FhALX4X08Mkq3-OC76Ko3rycQK9avBf9675X3~J3IWL6MPAl~G29D1r6tae31kJhq8y1XaeazR3mTwZ9ZfcpR7gdZj~p2YtUTwWYM~EOUs-ab7vf-9GKCdoanrTwthPSyniGIGpp~xEybIjxYVosP7pil4WWoK5NkGbvTgWkmlmQu32qPVy5SFsbSvFHfXiQw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Per Fig.\u00a07, using only mock observations with $|\\Delta m_{\\rm red}-\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$. This leaves 110 mock observations, all of which converge to the unmicrolensed baseline within the applied limit. This cut results in improved recovery of the input power-law index p in the range $\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 1.0$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991340/sty1793fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991340\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=B7~kM7qBp118I0TjJPYwpVjcquQQ9iNVQeDid3mqwzafUO~f75R4GTTXuA9qciU2~BTXC5ij4EPerJmXaI7~kEpJySFuC22JmvepwZlfgr~BaL2iuIJOTpQkmci3QKwPilvfT4uB4P-nF1ru6zVg~04~uJUI-dK1GT~1OcjHGekRtvDoJ4kmhoIvYqc~06-USK9Q2Mrsw-dlVUJf5tup-dJz5Jj11D9M~llbZgjt3sPmv~xhMpcGSZ6s9UVyqWxCUCQDyUCJ0ryOKMmuaHT-ARIxNVFoSs29jFemhJeuVs1LviUqceLcUgy0H94ECAFUtLku8BhmsP7fEL7lErscKw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991340&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Per Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, using only mock observations with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red}-\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>. This leaves 110 mock observations, all of which converge to the unmicrolensed baseline within the applied limit. This cut results in improved recovery of the input power-law index <em>p</em> in the range <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 1.0$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=1UPsHkST4xabypdxCCzXIbBcdhx5oStAC8X71tVe7X27hOUmN~v-~ao7AZNJQ3dmRCXoAOVJ58PT7eVqbrsTh8aoOrVWrkErvbgTEQOmKLENTNiJasuZRF0kkA8BUVXlMa9Js2qZ35uyqGJ4~Sww9FhALX4X08Mkq3-OC76Ko3rycQK9avBf9675X3~J3IWL6MPAl~G29D1r6tae31kJhq8y1XaeazR3mTwZ9ZfcpR7gdZj~p2YtUTwWYM~EOUs-ab7vf-9GKCdoanrTwthPSyniGIGpp~xEybIjxYVosP7pil4WWoK5NkGbvTgWkmlmQu32qPVy5SFsbSvFHfXiQw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Per Fig.\u00a07, using only mock observations with $|\\Delta m_{\\rm red}-\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$. This leaves 110 mock observations, all of which converge to the unmicrolensed baseline within the applied limit. This cut results in improved recovery of the input power-law index p in the range $\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 1.0$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991340/sty1793fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991340\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=B7~kM7qBp118I0TjJPYwpVjcquQQ9iNVQeDid3mqwzafUO~f75R4GTTXuA9qciU2~BTXC5ij4EPerJmXaI7~kEpJySFuC22JmvepwZlfgr~BaL2iuIJOTpQkmci3QKwPilvfT4uB4P-nF1ru6zVg~04~uJUI-dK1GT~1OcjHGekRtvDoJ4kmhoIvYqc~06-USK9Q2Mrsw-dlVUJf5tup-dJz5Jj11D9M~llbZgjt3sPmv~xhMpcGSZ6s9UVyqWxCUCQDyUCJ0ryOKMmuaHT-ARIxNVFoSs29jFemhJeuVs1LviUqceLcUgy0H94ECAFUtLku8BhmsP7fEL7lErscKw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991340&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Per Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, using only mock observations with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red}-\\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>. This leaves 110 mock observations, all of which converge to the unmicrolensed baseline within the applied limit. This cut results in improved recovery of the input power-law index <em>p</em> in the range <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 1.0$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> clearly shows that in our suite of 200 mock observations, we are able to reliably recover the input value of <em>p</em> = 1.5 in ensemble measurements if we restrict ourselves to observations with chromatic variation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gt 0.4$|\u2060</span>, and convergence to the macromagnification of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro} \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991342 id=\"118991342\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-3>7.3 Ensemble measurements</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">These mock simulations imply that using observations with low chromatic variation leads to systematically underestimating the temperature profile power-law index <em>p</em>. This bias towards smaller <em>p</em> in low chromatic variation observations can be particularly misleading when combining data. We illustrate this in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. Here, we have randomly selected eight mock observations and combined their likelihood surfaces to mimic the analysis in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (with the caveat that all of our mock simulations use the same lensing parameters, appropriate for MG 0414+0534, rather than eight separate systems).</p>                        <a id=\"118991344\" scrollto-destination=\"118991344\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=YugvBC70ywpLVAWSa49EJOLbtEF4Pf5KauEPGAST0fhgBO2nTHZmL6M8tfG46FabzZoYeA6jwRyTZw3A4UbSWfpEVkxiXsPdwqssDuvK9rP3puU1AYDLVOvqxkp4Ojl-~b7qu2WKl-K1pdETeM4drKQNkfxVeHjTSy3b664ijtqkDDMHox8rbsn-iM4h0y-AJ0uE5EyDDb~9q-rbz2xNKARA~scb9-JD49L-N5xeXxcYEk2prF8WH3~tZ44YMwugyQS~ydfhkaoNamzlB9ITFLLGulhFTajJ37Ma~HnjM52qVEHCeWgG4D00Jfz0d8C2gRqs9-2lStSfFq1WvFZv9Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustrative constraints obtained by combining eight randomly chosen mock observations of an accretion disc with p = 1.5, ln(rs/light-day) = 1.0 (red star and dashed red lines), as per Fig.\u00a02. Panel (a) shows the results when combining observations constrained to match the range of chromatic variation seen in the JV14 data. Panel (b) shows the combination of observations chosen without restriction from our mock data. In Panel (c) we combine mock observations using constraints on chromatic variation and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline described in Section\u00a07.2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991344/sty1793fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991344\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=WCXBXYd7RuXtzVogIZZmwn9Zm-XheoY-DUckuG3oxJUQjPz7tC9zreqWw-JsojY0eiQ14uic95PCSiffst71AOA72lRPur5J4DRdoPdc-PLNZhJTEHZfhIgV8DC8mWSBNvgru9yd3ZMRjiTlcbsbxah09geFjHtRvSFTN82A5qe-lByLUFE2vyYLTl8k7SyhUBpiiosjH1LN-iexya41aZ3KEzpbx9Rb9lTGAHTqVGMPUEUrhlb7dSCZ2P9tc-c144hvCBbB3qGYaeG3WF9c6N5KEf5p7zexiyQdvMVjRlqCxhcFO8zQ6X6-eTACqXrEHb7G-H9fCvW8RNC08RrIiA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991344&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustrative constraints obtained by combining eight randomly chosen mock observations of an accretion disc with <em>p</em> = 1.5, <em>ln</em>(<em>r<sub>s</sub></em>/light-day) = 1.0 (red star and dashed red lines), as per Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Panel (a) shows the results when combining observations constrained to match the range of chromatic variation seen in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> data. Panel (b) shows the combination of observations chosen without restriction from our mock data. In Panel (c) we combine mock observations using constraints on chromatic variation and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec7-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7.2</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=YugvBC70ywpLVAWSa49EJOLbtEF4Pf5KauEPGAST0fhgBO2nTHZmL6M8tfG46FabzZoYeA6jwRyTZw3A4UbSWfpEVkxiXsPdwqssDuvK9rP3puU1AYDLVOvqxkp4Ojl-~b7qu2WKl-K1pdETeM4drKQNkfxVeHjTSy3b664ijtqkDDMHox8rbsn-iM4h0y-AJ0uE5EyDDb~9q-rbz2xNKARA~scb9-JD49L-N5xeXxcYEk2prF8WH3~tZ44YMwugyQS~ydfhkaoNamzlB9ITFLLGulhFTajJ37Ma~HnjM52qVEHCeWgG4D00Jfz0d8C2gRqs9-2lStSfFq1WvFZv9Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustrative constraints obtained by combining eight randomly chosen mock observations of an accretion disc with p = 1.5, ln(rs/light-day) = 1.0 (red star and dashed red lines), as per Fig.\u00a02. Panel (a) shows the results when combining observations constrained to match the range of chromatic variation seen in the JV14 data. Panel (b) shows the combination of observations chosen without restriction from our mock data. In Panel (c) we combine mock observations using constraints on chromatic variation and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline described in Section\u00a07.2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991344/sty1793fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991344\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=WCXBXYd7RuXtzVogIZZmwn9Zm-XheoY-DUckuG3oxJUQjPz7tC9zreqWw-JsojY0eiQ14uic95PCSiffst71AOA72lRPur5J4DRdoPdc-PLNZhJTEHZfhIgV8DC8mWSBNvgru9yd3ZMRjiTlcbsbxah09geFjHtRvSFTN82A5qe-lByLUFE2vyYLTl8k7SyhUBpiiosjH1LN-iexya41aZ3KEzpbx9Rb9lTGAHTqVGMPUEUrhlb7dSCZ2P9tc-c144hvCBbB3qGYaeG3WF9c6N5KEf5p7zexiyQdvMVjRlqCxhcFO8zQ6X6-eTACqXrEHb7G-H9fCvW8RNC08RrIiA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991344&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustrative constraints obtained by combining eight randomly chosen mock observations of an accretion disc with <em>p</em> = 1.5, <em>ln</em>(<em>r<sub>s</sub></em>/light-day) = 1.0 (red star and dashed red lines), as per Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Panel (a) shows the results when combining observations constrained to match the range of chromatic variation seen in the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> data. Panel (b) shows the combination of observations chosen without restriction from our mock data. In Panel (c) we combine mock observations using constraints on chromatic variation and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec7-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7.2</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we combine the likelihood surfaces for eight random mock observations that match the range in chromatic variation displayed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (in that work, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.04 \\lt \\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.52$|\u2060</span>; we use <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.6$|\u2060</span>). These combined observations miss the input <em>p</em> (red star) at greater than the 95 per cent level, instead returning a much lower value in line with the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> constraint (<em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2). In the middle panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we simply combine eight random observations, imposing no constraints. Although the measured <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> and <em>p</em> are marginally closer to the input values in this case, they still undershoot <em>p</em> at greater than the 95 per cent level. This is due to the prevalence of low chromatic variation observations in our mock sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>, we restrict ourselves to mock simulations meeting the suitability criteria discussed in previous paragraphs (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gt 0.4$|\u2060</span>; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro} \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>). Here, we accurately recover the input <em>p</em>, although there is some evidence in this example combination that we still overestimate the size of the accretion disc <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We can make this argument more robust by generating <em>N</em> realizations of eight mock observations each, effectively repeating a <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>-like experiment <em>N</em> times. We can then explore the probability distributions for the recovered <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> and <em>p</em> across the <em>N</em> realizations, using various subsets of the data: completely random, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>-like (i.e. low chromatic variation), or constrained (i.e. imposing minimum conditions on degree of chromatic variation and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given our sample of 200 mock observations, we choose <em>N</em> = 10. This gives us sufficient mock data points for statistically independent measurements even when we apply restrictions to our sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, we plot the results of this experiment. The left-hand panel shows the combined probability distribution for accretion disc size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> of <em>N</em> = 10 realizations of eight mock observations each. The right-hand panel shows the distribution for power-law index <em>p</em>. The solid grey histograms are drawn randomly from the full 200 mock observations. The blue hatched histograms represent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>-like data sets, with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.6$|\u2060</span>. The red cross-hatched histograms are the result of applying minimum criteria to our mock data: that they display chromatic variation <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gt 0.4$|\u2060</span>, and roughly converge to the unmicrolensed baseline as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro} \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"118991350\" scrollto-destination=\"118991350\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=YT4KcYVpeEhP8iVCJbtiFT2rLfkzsNUfIfMwUz7nG1IvH7Fh2~BmZhoZM6womq3zTmNRR77UqXFGuj5LunE-yMHOwPejADrvuAqOMH3rIx~da3dVAZXJ7S2vMYeOACy7I3hivJTuIIPGt98BbTRBFGHLlnFjtURQpVeEZtQetZKM1bVgVeb10sQA~DZ7IK4oNGVWSynvrZgPzp7ptRoS6-hkH7XLkDFK5TJWWVQc~bhuVwqTEZw9xWDd0m9nOlBCIa9PE4j5JCvavmxfJF0mLs4kyWEDj4oSvOW6pZdMOMD0tFIDfV6~nGcqPYJNhjySvcyCSZ2SKqxEghQT68yrpw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Attempted recovery of input accretion disc parameters (black dashed line) using ten realizations each consisting of eight mock observations drawn from our mock simulation suite. The combined probability distributions are for accretion disc size rs (left-hand panel) and temperature profile p (right-hand panel). The solid grey histograms represent completely random draws from the full simulation suite. The blue hatched histograms correspond to JV14-like systems, where only low chromatic variation is observed ($\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.6$). The red histograms correspond to the case where we apply selection criteria to the data: that a minimum chromatic variation of $\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} = 0.4$ is observed, and that the observations roughly converge to the unmicrolensed baseline in the reddest filter ($|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$). Only in this latter case do we correctly recover the input power-law index p; all cases tend to overestimate the accretion disc size.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991350/sty1793fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991350\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=YGYBzD~PwyhKhxr4bqEfydxMuCAaUnNhivnFi7GGPxEOatH1stcVvN3~pMs1jfFQuy3KFkIerhMeC38dF9~sMrbNuT08a-sA1J1fIYAlb2DRSyo57PdCDazj8pgZO1PB-F5AIdru3-mQkqLpSZcH1m5mK8aBjSSkujlX4o5T9jbylY2OIKkyYjR76Lm7E0VkqpYgytdeDJv6nasSYuiE8v5pHN1n8MFZFaWyy-4ozhCo8S2qDph~CPMSjkhv1ye9SOeGIKVvJYKzKRmyq~WUhAAHQLzFGqX-AoDcVr2QXcY2GVcd4Pb5uKOzj~CGHRTt03eUystOkvrLBE2uoykKOQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991350&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Attempted recovery of input accretion disc parameters (black dashed line) using ten realizations each consisting of eight mock observations drawn from our mock simulation suite. The combined probability distributions are for accretion disc size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> (left-hand panel) and temperature profile <em>p</em> (right-hand panel). The solid grey histograms represent completely random draws from the full simulation suite. The blue hatched histograms correspond to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>-like systems, where only low chromatic variation is observed (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.6$|\u2060</span>). The red histograms correspond to the case where we apply selection criteria to the data: that a minimum chromatic variation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} = 0.4$|</span> is observed, and that the observations roughly converge to the unmicrolensed baseline in the reddest filter (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>). Only in this latter case do we correctly recover the input power-law index <em>p</em>; all cases tend to overestimate the accretion disc size.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=YT4KcYVpeEhP8iVCJbtiFT2rLfkzsNUfIfMwUz7nG1IvH7Fh2~BmZhoZM6womq3zTmNRR77UqXFGuj5LunE-yMHOwPejADrvuAqOMH3rIx~da3dVAZXJ7S2vMYeOACy7I3hivJTuIIPGt98BbTRBFGHLlnFjtURQpVeEZtQetZKM1bVgVeb10sQA~DZ7IK4oNGVWSynvrZgPzp7ptRoS6-hkH7XLkDFK5TJWWVQc~bhuVwqTEZw9xWDd0m9nOlBCIa9PE4j5JCvavmxfJF0mLs4kyWEDj4oSvOW6pZdMOMD0tFIDfV6~nGcqPYJNhjySvcyCSZ2SKqxEghQT68yrpw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Attempted recovery of input accretion disc parameters (black dashed line) using ten realizations each consisting of eight mock observations drawn from our mock simulation suite. The combined probability distributions are for accretion disc size rs (left-hand panel) and temperature profile p (right-hand panel). The solid grey histograms represent completely random draws from the full simulation suite. The blue hatched histograms correspond to JV14-like systems, where only low chromatic variation is observed ($\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.6$). The red histograms correspond to the case where we apply selection criteria to the data: that a minimum chromatic variation of $\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} = 0.4$ is observed, and that the observations roughly converge to the unmicrolensed baseline in the reddest filter ($|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$). Only in this latter case do we correctly recover the input power-law index p; all cases tend to overestimate the accretion disc size.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991350/sty1793fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991350\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=YGYBzD~PwyhKhxr4bqEfydxMuCAaUnNhivnFi7GGPxEOatH1stcVvN3~pMs1jfFQuy3KFkIerhMeC38dF9~sMrbNuT08a-sA1J1fIYAlb2DRSyo57PdCDazj8pgZO1PB-F5AIdru3-mQkqLpSZcH1m5mK8aBjSSkujlX4o5T9jbylY2OIKkyYjR76Lm7E0VkqpYgytdeDJv6nasSYuiE8v5pHN1n8MFZFaWyy-4ozhCo8S2qDph~CPMSjkhv1ye9SOeGIKVvJYKzKRmyq~WUhAAHQLzFGqX-AoDcVr2QXcY2GVcd4Pb5uKOzj~CGHRTt03eUystOkvrLBE2uoykKOQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991350&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Attempted recovery of input accretion disc parameters (black dashed line) using ten realizations each consisting of eight mock observations drawn from our mock simulation suite. The combined probability distributions are for accretion disc size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> (left-hand panel) and temperature profile <em>p</em> (right-hand panel). The solid grey histograms represent completely random draws from the full simulation suite. The blue hatched histograms correspond to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>-like systems, where only low chromatic variation is observed (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lt 0.6$|\u2060</span>). The red histograms correspond to the case where we apply selection criteria to the data: that a minimum chromatic variation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} = 0.4$|</span> is observed, and that the observations roughly converge to the unmicrolensed baseline in the reddest filter (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lt 0.3$|\u2060</span>). Only in this latter case do we correctly recover the input power-law index <em>p</em>; all cases tend to overestimate the accretion disc size.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In all three cases, we systematically overestimate the size of the accretion disc <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>, by a factor of\u00a0\u223c1.5\u20132.0. We note that even if selection effects in our data are leading to a factor of 2 overestimation of accretion disc size, the sizes derived from microlensing observations are typically still larger than expected from thin disc theory.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Constraining the mock observations to match the degree of chromatic variation observed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> leads to a systematic underestimation of the power-law index <em>p</em>. In fact, the result we recover here is identical to the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> result: 0.8 \u00b1 0.2. If we randomly select instead from the full suite of mock observations, the recovered value of <em>p</em> = 1.0 \u00b1 0.2 shifts slightly closer to the true value, but still predicts a steeper temperature profile at greater than the 2\u03c3 level. When we apply constraints on both degree of chromatic variation and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline, we correctly recover the input value of <em>p</em> = 1.5 (formal measured constraint <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p=1.5^{+0.3}_{-0.2}$|\u2060</span>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991353 id=\"118991353\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-4>7.4 Comparison with observed data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">There are other observations in the literature which use the same technique as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> and this paper to constrain quasar accretion discs. It is interesting to see whether they see similar trends. Rojas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) presented single-epoch observations (spectra, in this case) of two systems: HE 0047-1756 and SDSS 1155+6346. In both systems, the observed chromatic variation exceeds the rough threshold we find here of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gtrsim 0.4$|\u2060</span>. In contrast to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, and in line with the general trend observed in this paper, they find <em>p</em> = 2.3 \u00b1 0.8 for HE 0047-1756 (which displays the most chromatic variation) and 1.5 \u00b1 0.6 for SDSS 1155+6346.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Motta et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) analysed spectra for three systems: HE 0435-1223, WFI 2033-4723, and HE 2149-2745. Their observed chromatic variations are low: 0.28, 0.26, and 0.11, respectively (the variation in WFI 2033-4723 is the average of four separate epochs of data). As expected, they predict lower values of <em>p</em>. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, we plot all of these observational constraints: our data, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, Rojas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and Motta et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> and <em>p</em>, along with the binned constraints from our mock observations. We note that these are not technically directly comparable \u2013 the observed data are for a range of systems, whereas the mock results are for repeated observations of a single system. Nevertheless, they all follow the same basic trend.</p>                        <a id=\"118991356\" scrollto-destination=\"118991356\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=1DfwMHA6UHm1LQw4rkBIGllMvNBMXLqmBezyLsz~qAg-Ms77oqOCAedGmm2-2ylqOn67Nvc73z45tM0F60xOEdtmq8KPh~4d6eDl2OhJQca63NejxVa8sqoynTEsjiT1EQCrdqSw7GEGpWzRuRBUKmqwdQdqpYdKY9pXkHb7wpk79yXuG3RrcSgN~v344kT0AoGdV7tinRC1nbR0b-quzuidfBGfhle28ahqN-qgci8CzGMJMy4zKfjS04klzWNRAv2TOcECUU4y5D2b8D3xQ2S8Hzr0enSzGYrEWH7kxjk-j-r5~BbaiiyL-dREIPIWtRy-jE4AWwst0yvXKtAmjg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A comparison of mock constraints on rs (top panel) and p (bottom panel) as a function of chromatic variation, with measurements taken from the literature. Mock data are black crosses, per Figs\u00a06 and\u00a07. Red stars: B 1422+231, MG 0414+0534, WFI J2026-4536 (left to right, this work). Light blue circle: a combination of eight quasars (Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. 2014). Magenta triangles: HE 0047-1756 and SDSS 1155+6346 (left to right, Rojas et\u00a0al. 2014). Green squares: HE 2149-2745, WFI 2033-4723 (combination of four independent observations), HE 0435-1223 (left to right, Motta et\u00a0al. 2017).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991356/sty1793fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991356\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=ypaFAat2LTKjwwsG675Nwy7aPYKxwZ6eJBhCjdXiU2YgYasTOalaC5RmQkSUsmY~lCIaVOpkfpIZjWBAR7IG~DxeuAaRoCnLK~WEYKLUDzdKFm1IHiOwWBNhyuUjHv7Cd8XyELYykixC7u5oXdaQm1se423JuA8jka9a-9XHO6ihLoFoA8FYOxy~8P~okQa62DynhfGSbn6qPSAdP6HE9cHl4sG1NcvuudlZTzhKOiCwOnBg3DBbJ6c-3eHTPb1OetEIUdeYxeQFVCYF7eGsNxbbELDm1JjJ30nV2tAiBVFHg4JnO6PfFiPubu5SVOmDtaB1YaVJR1TfKV5XE9iZeQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991356&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison of mock constraints on <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> (top panel) and <em>p</em> (bottom panel) as a function of chromatic variation, with measurements taken from the literature. Mock data are black crosses, per Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. Red stars: B 1422+231, MG 0414+0534, WFI J2026-4536 (left to right, this work). Light blue circle: a combination of eight quasars (Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Magenta triangles: HE 0047-1756 and SDSS 1155+6346 (left to right, Rojas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Green squares: HE 2149-2745, WFI 2033-4723 (combination of four independent observations), HE 0435-1223 (left to right, Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/m_sty1793fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&amp;Signature=1DfwMHA6UHm1LQw4rkBIGllMvNBMXLqmBezyLsz~qAg-Ms77oqOCAedGmm2-2ylqOn67Nvc73z45tM0F60xOEdtmq8KPh~4d6eDl2OhJQca63NejxVa8sqoynTEsjiT1EQCrdqSw7GEGpWzRuRBUKmqwdQdqpYdKY9pXkHb7wpk79yXuG3RrcSgN~v344kT0AoGdV7tinRC1nbR0b-quzuidfBGfhle28ahqN-qgci8CzGMJMy4zKfjS04klzWNRAv2TOcECUU4y5D2b8D3xQ2S8Hzr0enSzGYrEWH7kxjk-j-r5~BbaiiyL-dREIPIWtRy-jE4AWwst0yvXKtAmjg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A comparison of mock constraints on rs (top panel) and p (bottom panel) as a function of chromatic variation, with measurements taken from the literature. Mock data are black crosses, per Figs\u00a06 and\u00a07. Red stars: B 1422+231, MG 0414+0534, WFI J2026-4536 (left to right, this work). Light blue circle: a combination of eight quasars (Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. 2014). Magenta triangles: HE 0047-1756 and SDSS 1155+6346 (left to right, Rojas et\u00a0al. 2014). Green squares: HE 2149-2745, WFI 2033-4723 (combination of four independent observations), HE 0435-1223 (left to right, Motta et\u00a0al. 2017).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118991356/sty1793fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118991356\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/4/10.1093_mnras_sty1793/1/sty1793fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465762&Signature=ypaFAat2LTKjwwsG675Nwy7aPYKxwZ6eJBhCjdXiU2YgYasTOalaC5RmQkSUsmY~lCIaVOpkfpIZjWBAR7IG~DxeuAaRoCnLK~WEYKLUDzdKFm1IHiOwWBNhyuUjHv7Cd8XyELYykixC7u5oXdaQm1se423JuA8jka9a-9XHO6ihLoFoA8FYOxy~8P~okQa62DynhfGSbn6qPSAdP6HE9cHl4sG1NcvuudlZTzhKOiCwOnBg3DBbJ6c-3eHTPb1OetEIUdeYxeQFVCYF7eGsNxbbELDm1JjJ30nV2tAiBVFHg4JnO6PfFiPubu5SVOmDtaB1YaVJR1TfKV5XE9iZeQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118991356&ar=5050072&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1793fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison of mock constraints on <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> (top panel) and <em>p</em> (bottom panel) as a function of chromatic variation, with measurements taken from the literature. Mock data are black crosses, per Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. Red stars: B 1422+231, MG 0414+0534, WFI J2026-4536 (left to right, this work). Light blue circle: a combination of eight quasars (Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Magenta triangles: HE 0047-1756 and SDSS 1155+6346 (left to right, Rojas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Green squares: HE 2149-2745, WFI 2033-4723 (combination of four independent observations), HE 0435-1223 (left to right, Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991357 id=\"118991357\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-5>7.5 Mock observation selection effect discussion</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We propose here that there are two selection effects that lead to systematically underestimating <em>p</em> in single-epoch microlensing simulations: chromatic variation, and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline. Both of these degeneracies are straightforward to understand in the context of convolving a power-law accretion disc model with microlensing magnification maps. When chromatic variations are low, the blue (hotter) and red (colder) parts of the accretion disc are similarly affected by microlensing. Preferred solutions then become accretion disc models where size depends only weakly on wavelength (<em>p</em> is low). It is easier to find positions on the magnification map that produce similar microlensing amplitudes if the relative sizes of the blue and red parts of the accretion disc are similar.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An observed flux ratio in the reddest filter that is significantly offset from the unmicrolensed baseline is easier to produce if the reddest emission region is small. Given that we constrain the accretion disc model to be a power law, if the reddest emission region is small we have less freedom to choose large values for the power-law index <em>p</em> (due to both the constraints on the resolution of our simulations, and physical limits, i.e. the optical/UV accretion disc cannot extend below the innermost stable orbit).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These findings are related to our earlier observation that small magnitude differences between images provide very little information on the size of the quasar accretion disc (Bate et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). If we insist that the reddest filter roughly converges to the unmicrolensed baseline, then a low degree of chromatic variation means we are learning almost nothing about the accretion disc (size or temperature profile). If the reddest filter <em>does not</em> converge to the unmicrolensed baseline, we may get a tight constraint on size, but <em>p</em> will be artificially driven to low values for the reasons described above.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991361 id=\"118991361\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-6>7.6 Possible consequences for ensemble measurements</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have demonstrated the selection effects in the previous section for only one simulated accretion disc, with <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> = 2.7 light-days and <em>p</em> = 1.5. The possible consequences of these effects on real ensemble measurements depend on their generalizability. We discuss the three possible cases below: (a) our results are perfectly general; (b) the trends in our results are general; and (c) our results are not general.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991363 id=\"118991363\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=SECT7-6-1>(a) All results are perfectly general</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the case where our results are fully general, the selection effects discussed in the previous section hold for all ensemble single-epoch measurements of accretion disc parameters. We can use the following thresholds to ensure that any ensemble of real observed quasars are providing us with accurate measurements of the underlying disc temperature profile: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}| \\lesssim 0.3$|\u2060</span>, and</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gtrsim 0.4$|\u2060</span>.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The simplest option for lensed quasar observations that do not meet these requirements is to reject them. If however our results are truly general, then it may be possible to correct for the trends observed in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. How to do so in an observed data set, where you have no knowledge of the true accretion disc temperature profile, is not clear.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991366 id=\"118991366\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=SECT7-6-2>(b) Only trends are general</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this case, the general trend that low chromatic variation observations lead to underestimating <em>p</em> is true, but the exact shape of the trend depends on some other parameters: perhaps the lens model, or the smooth matter fraction, or the underlying accretion disc temperature profile. In this situation, the thresholds in case (a) might not be universally applicable \u2013 lower chromatic variation observations may be usable in some cases, and misleading in others.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If the shape of these trends depends on external parameters such as the lens model, then we can hopefully account for them by adding a systematic component to our error budgets. If the shape of the trends depends on the underlying accretion disc, the situation is more complicated. Since we have no knowledge of the true temperature profile in a set of real observations, we will not know which of our data are usable. Our best hope in this case is to run suites of mock simulations for various input accretion discs, and determine which ranges of the data return correct results irrespective of the input disc.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, in this case it becomes crucially important whether high chromatic variation leads to a corresponding <em>over-</em>estimation of <em>p</em>. If it does, then any usability thresholds on chromatic variation are likely to be both upper and lower limits; blindly applying a lower limit only might bias us to high <em>p</em>, just as using low chromatic variation biases us towards low <em>p</em>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118991370 id=\"118991370\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=SECT7-6-3>(c) Results are not general</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have demonstrated here that low chromatic variation observations do not lead to correct recovery of the input accretion disc for <em>p</em> = 1.5. We can imagine, however, that this result is not general \u2013 perhaps the single-epoch method correctly measures accretion disc temperature profiles if they are steep (say, <em>p</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a01), but fails to do so if they are shallower (as we have shown for <em>p</em> = 1.5). This is the worst-case scenario: given a low chromatic variation observation and no knowledge of the true disc temperature profile, we cannot tell whether our measurement is due to the disc itself or a selection effect.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At this stage, we have no reason to suspect that this case is true. We can think of no <em>a priori</em> reason why the method would work well for one mock accretion disc, and fail for another. Nevertheless, our current set of mock simulations do not allow us to rule this case out; we include it here for completeness.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on our mock simulations, <em>in all three cases described above</em> we must currently doubt the results of any analyses that make use of ensembles of low chromatic variation observations. If cases (a) or (b) are true, we know that such ensembles are likely to underestimate <em>p</em> (although, if case (b) is true, we cannot yet be sure where the cutoff in the usefulness of data occurs). If case (c) is true, we (currently) have no way to differentiate between a situation where the true underlying disc has a steep temperature profile and we are correctly measuring it, or it has a shallow temperature profile and we are underestimating it (as in our mock simulations).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our analysis for <em>p</em> = 1.5 accretion discs only does not provide enough information to discern between cases (a), (b), or (c). To do so, we need a suite of mock observations that covers the full range of astrophysically interesting parameter space: plausible accretion disc temperature profiles, lens models, smooth matter fractions, chromatic variation, and so on. Given the significant computational resources required for such a task, we plan to undertake it in a subsequent paper.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118991375 id=\"118991375\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7-7>7.7 Additional simulation caveats</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In our mock simulations we have made two additional simplifying assumptions: we have used only microlensing parameters appropriate for an MG 0414+0534-like system, and we have assumed that all of the microlensing is in a single image (<em>A</em><sub>2</sub>, the saddle point image). We will discuss some implications of these choices below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">MG 0414+0534 is a high-magnification system (\u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a025 in the close image pair), with a high density of caustics in its magnification maps. The models used in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> have lensed images with a wide range of magnifications, from \u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5 to \u03bc\u00a0\u223c\u00a025. The impact of caustic density on our ability to recover accretion disc parameters with the single-epoch technique has not yet been fully explored. Previous analyses, such as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, assume that it makes no difference \u2013 that accretion disc parameters are recovered equally-correctly in low and high magnification systems. We take the same position here. This assumption is circumstantially supported by the similarity between the trend in constraints from our mock observations (using only one set of microlensing parameters) and observations in the literature (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec7-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7.4</a> and especially Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>), however it should be more fully tested in the future.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have also assumed that all of the microlensing is occurring in the saddle point image <em>A</em><sub>2</sub>. It is common in spectroscopic observations of microlensed quasars to find that only one image is strongly affected (see e.g. MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; O\u2019Dowd et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and saddle point images in close image pairs are known to be more strongly effected by microlensing (Schechter &amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Vernardos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Nevertheless, by restricting the microlensing to a single image we do exclude some chromatic signatures from our sample of mock observations. In particular, cases where shorter wavelengths in image <em>A</em><sub>1</sub> are heavily microlensed, leading to an inverted chromatic microlensing curve (this is the case in two of the eight systems presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mock observations presented here are not intended to be exhaustive. They are, however, all plausible realizations of chromatic microlensing observations in a system like MG 0414+0534; if the standard single-epoch microlensing technique is free of systematic or selection effects, we should recover the input accretion disc parameters correctly. In future work, we will extend our mock observations to cover all of the plausible microlensing parameter space. This will allow us to robustly demonstrate the impact of these selection effects on single-epoch microlensing measurements in a fully realistic sample of lensed quasars.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991380 id=\"118991380\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>8 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we have presented single-epoch <em>HST</em> observations of four gravitationally lensed quasars: MG 0414+0534; RXJ 0911+0551; B 1422+231; and WFI J2026-4536. In each system, we have focussed on close image pairs, where time delays are expected to be negligible. Since we are confident that these images capture the background quasar in the same state, we can use any microlensing-induced chromatic variation to place constraints on the emission regions in the quasar.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our observations were tuned, as far as was possible, to avoid broad emission lines and therefore provide a clean measurement of microlensing on the quasar accretion discs. Other effects can also masquerade as chromatic microlensing \u2013 most notably differential extinction. We have not attempted to isolate these effects; we assume that the entirety of the chromatic variation is due to microlensing.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the observed magnitude differences between close image pairs, we place constraints on the size <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> of the quasar accretion disc at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda _0 =1026\\,$|</span>\u00c5 (rest wavelength) and the power-law index <em>p</em> relating accretion disc radius to rest wavelength. We assume an accretion disc spectral profile of the form <em>r</em> = <em>r<sub>s</sub></em>(\u03bb/\u03bb<sub>0</sub>)<sup><em>p</em></sup>. Our simulation technique broadly follows that of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, an extension of Bate et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Floyd et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Across our four systems, we find a broad diversity in the measured power-law index <em>p</em>, from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p=1.4^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span> in B 1422+231, to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p = 2.3^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span> in WFI J2026-4536at 68 per cent confidence (assuming smooth matter fraction <em>s</em> = 0.8). This is somewhat at odds with the constraints in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a>, which cluster around <em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2 (their 68 per cent Bayesian constraint obtained by combining observations from eight systems).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is a trend in our constraints towards larger values of <em>p</em> when the degree of chromatic variation in our observations is greater. To explore the origin of this trend, we generated a suite of 200 blinded mock observations with a known input accretion disc (<em>r<sub>s</sub></em> = 2.7 light-days, <em>p</em> = 1.5). Accretion disc constraints obtained using the standard single-epoch analysis technique on these mock observations display the following trends: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">In cases where the chromatic variation between the bluest and reddest filters in the mock observations is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\lesssim 0.4$|\u2060</span>, the single-epoch technique systematically underestimates <em>p</em>. Combining multiple mock observations with low chromatic variation in the usual way exacerbates this problem.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">In cases where the mock flux ratio in the reddest filter differs significantly from the unmicrolensed baseline (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}|\\gtrsim 0.3$|\u2060</span>), the measured <em>p</em> is once again underestimated.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, when chromatic variation in the mock observations is sufficiently large, and approximately converges towards the unmicrolensed baseline in the reddest filter, the single-epoch technique correctly recovers input accretion disc power-law index.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This leads to the following important conclusions: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The combined constraint published in Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) of <em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2, as well as those in Motta et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), are likely driven by the low degree of chromatic variation in the ensemble of lensed quasars used in those studies.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Under the assumption that chromatic variations of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gtrsim 0.4$|</span> produce clean measurements of the accretion disc temperature profile (implied by our mock observations), we have two systems of interest: MG 0414+0534and WFI J2026-4536. Here, we find very high estimates of <em>p</em>: 1.8 \u00b1 0.6 in MG 0414+0534, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.3^{+0.5}_{-0.4}$|</span> in WFI J2026-4536 (assuming <em>s</em> = 0.8). These correspond to shallower temperature profiles than expected from an SS disc, more in line with Abramowicz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) slim discs. If these measurements are accurate, they are consistent with the picture that emerges from both microlensing and reverberation mapping analyses, which generically predict larger accretion discs at a given temperature than expected from SS discs.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We conclude that there are important selection effects that need to be taken into consideration when using the single-epoch microlensing technique to measure accretion disc temperature profiles. First, this technique should be applied to ensembles of quasars \u2013 measurements from individual objects have large scatter which does not necessarily reflect anything physical in the source. Secondly, combined results using this technique might be misleading if the chromatic variation is low, or the observations do not roughly converge to the unmicrolensed baseline in the reddest filter. In our mock experiments with <em>r<sub>s</sub></em> = 2.7 light-days and <em>p</em> = 1.5, we find that the following criteria are sufficient to correctly recover the input values: chromatic variation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta m_{\\rm max} - \\Delta m_{\\rm min} \\gtrsim 0.4$|\u2060</span>, and convergence to the unmicrolensed baseline of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta m_{\\rm red} - \\Delta m_{\\rm macro}|\\lesssim 0.3$|\u2060</span>. Further simulations are required to determine if these thresholds are universally applicable. However, even when these criteria are applied, the technique may still overestimate accretion disc sizes by roughly a factor of 1.5 to 2.0.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have conducted only a preliminary exploration of these selection effects here. In particular, we note that the limits quoted in the previous paragraph were estimated using one specific set of microlensing parameters, appropriate for MG 0414+0534, and assuming that all of the microlensing was occurring in the saddle point image. These effects need to be systematically explored across astrophysically interesting parameter space if we are to confidently use the single-epoch technique for constraining quasar accretion discs. Detailed analysis of the impact of these effects on mock observations would allow us to construct more appropriate priors on our Bayesian measurements. We will pursue this task in a subsequent paper.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991389 id=\"118991389\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We wish to thank the anonymous referee for a thorough and thoughful review, which significantly improved this paper. Nicholas Bate thanks the STFC for support under Ernest Rutherford Grant ST/M003914/1. Based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>, obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. These observations are associated with <em>HST</em> Cycle 20 Program ID 12874, PI Floyd. Georgios Vernardos is supported through an NWO-VICI grant (project number 639.043.308). Rachel Webster acknowledges the support of ARC Grant DP150101727. This work was performed on the gSTAR national facility at Swinburne University of Technology. gSTAR is funded by Swinburne and the Australian Government\u2019s Education Investment Fund.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991391 id=\"118991391\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://physics.rutgers.edu/~keeton/gravlens/2012WS/\" target=\"_blank\">http://physics.rutgers.edu/~keeton/gravlens/2012WS/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://gerlumph.swin.edu.au\" target=\"_blank\">http://gerlumph.swin.edu.au</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118991394 id=\"118991394\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abajas</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Mediavilla</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">E.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Mu\u00f1oz</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J. "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">Why do we find such a variety of constraints on <em>p</em>, where the measurements in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> were largely consistent with each other, converging on <em>p</em> = 0.8 \u00b1 0.2? In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, we plot all of the observations reported in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">JV14</a> (black triangles, from their Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) and this paper (red circles). The figure shows absolute magnitude differences between lensed images as a function of rest wavelength in each quasar. The variation in absolute magnitude difference between shortest and longest wavelength represents the degree of microlensing-induced chromatic variation in each system."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 3": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 4": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 5": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 6": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 7": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 8": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 9": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 10": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}}}}, "Tables status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "HST imaging of four gravitationally lensed quasars", "authors": ["Bate, N. F.", "Vernardos, G.", "O'Dowd, M. J.", "Neri-Larios, D. M.", "Webster, R. L.", "Floyd, D. J. E.", "Barone-Nugent, R. L.", "Labrie, K.", "King, A. L.", "Yong, S. -Y."], "author_address": ["AA(Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK), AB(Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, PO Box 800, NL-9700AV Groningen, the Netherlands), AC(Department of Physics and Astronomy, Lehman College, City University of New York, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, Bronx, NY 10468-1589, USA; Department of Astrophysics, American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, NY 10024-5192, USA; The Graduate Center of the City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10016, USA), AD(School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia), AE(School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia), AF(School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia; School of Physics, Monash University, Clayton, VIC 3800, Australia; Monash Centre for Astrophysics, Monash University, Clayton, VIC 3800, Australia; Think Big Analytics, 3 London Bridge Street, London SE1 9SG, UK), AG(School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia), AH(Gemini Observatory, Hilo, HI 96720, USA), AI(School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia), AJ(School of Physics, The University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC 3010, Australia)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "479", "publication_year": "2018/10/1", "start_page": "4796", "end_page": "4814", "keywords": ["accretion", "accretion discs", "gravitational lensing: micro", "quasars: individual: MG 0414+0534", "quasars: individual: RXJ 0911+0551", "quasars: individual: B 1422+231", "quasars: individual: WFI J2026-4536", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.479.4796B", "abstract": "We present new Hubble Space Telescope WFC3 imaging of four gravitationally lensed quasars: MG 0414+0534; RXJ 0911+0551; B 1422+231; WFI J2026-4536. In three of these systems we detect wavelength-dependent microlensing, which we use to place constraints on the sizes and temperature profiles of the accretion discs in each quasar. Accretion disc radius is assumed to vary with wavelength according to the power-law relationship r \u221d \u03bb<SUP>p</SUP>, equivalent to a radial temperature profile of T \u221d r<SUP>-1/p</SUP>. The goal of this work is to search for deviations from standard thin disc theory, which predicts that radius goes as wavelength to the power p = 4/3. We find a wide range of power-law indices, from p=1.4^{+0.5}_{-0.4} in B 1422+231to p=2.3^{+0.5}_{-0.4} in WFI J2026-4536. The measured value of p appears to correlate with the strength of the wavelength-dependent microlensing. We explore this issue with mock simulations using a fixed accretion disc with p = 1.5, and find that cases where wavelength-dependent microlensing is small tend to underestimate the value of p. This casts doubt on previous ensemble single-epoch measurements which have favoured low values using samples of lensed quasars that display only moderate chromatic effects. Using only our systems with strong chromatic microlensing we prefer p &gt; 4/3, corresponding to shallower temperature profiles than expected from standard thin disc theory.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/sty1793", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1807.03553", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
